reviews.review_text: Spec Ops: The Line might be dismissed at first glance for being just another modern military shooter. That assumption couldn’t be more wrong though.  Based loosely on Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, Spec Ops provides one of the strongest and mature narratives in recent memory.  The story revolves around Captain Walker and his two wingmen, Lugo and Adams. Their latest mission sends them to a post-catastrophic Dubai to find Colonel Konrad who was in charge of evacuating the civilian population. Captain Walker is often forced to make difficult decisions and any pretense of him being some badass hero is quickly removed as it's clear that sometimes there's no correct decision to make. The character progression is strong and the voice acting is phenomenal.  The art direction is spectacular as Dubai provides almost a surreal experience. When you’re not avoiding sandstorms, you'll travel through luxury hotels and buildings that have all been submerged in sand. The game also gives you a taste of PTSD as you’re sometimes left wondering whether or not certain things are real.  The combat plays out similarly to other third person shooters. It will have you taking cover, blind firing and issuing commands to your squad mates. The AI is well done, making Lugo and Adams feel very capable while the enemy AI on the other hand could use a bit of work. The combat is solid but it makes no attempt to do anything new or innovative.  The soundtrack is fantastic, including a lot of real songs along with ambient guitar pieces that match the mood perfectly. The inclusion of Jimi Hendrix and other classics really give the game an ‘Apocalypse Now’ type of feel which was another Heart of Darkness adaptation.  Unfortunately, Spec Ops is fairly short (around 5 hours) but the different endings offer some incentive to replay the game. There’s a multiplayer mode that offers a few different game types, weapons, and stages but it feels a bit tacked on. It’s fairly clear that Spec Ops was designed to be experienced as a single player game primarily and it’s one I strongly recommend.  For a more detailed review, here’s a video by my friend and fellow reviewer, Trent:          YouTube™ Video:  Analog Reviews: Spec Ops: The Line

It's been a year since I picked up the game, and I still cannot bear to play it again when I think of what overcame me when I finished the game.  As my playtime indicates, I finished this in a massive rush. I played from 11pm to 4am, expecting that the game was some sort of quick-play game that I could put down easily at any time, like, say, call of duty (oh good grief, even the comparison makes me cringe). I was so driven to finish the game   (the mission, as it were) much like Walker was  . This revelation made me hate myself beyond belief, as I realized the very same determination, the self-same urge to commit to a goal made me ignore warning signs all over the place. This game makes you truly explore yourself, the deepest darkest recesses of your psyche where the hidden threads of psychopathy lie.   When I finally finished the game at 4am, I was unable to sleep. I stayed awake, tormented by what I had done   and the face of the white phosphorus burnt mother and child  . I kept telling myself: 'This is a game. Get over it and get to sleep.', but I just couldn't get over the fact that at the heart of every human is the capability to take things to an extreme in order to pursue a perceived greater good. It is the very thing that drives the best of humanity and the worst of humanity. Medical scientists pursuing a cure, versus the extremists ♥♥♥♥ing up Syria as I type this. This game revealed an inner heart of darkness that needs to be understood, addressed and controlled. If only every one of us could think about it with the due weight and clarity that is needed in such a discussion.  Play the game, and finish it, please. Do yourself a favour and finish it. Understand how dangerous it is to be unaware of your own actions, and bloody well learn from it.
you will hate yourself after finishing this game 10/10

Being from a military family, and being a soldier myself, I know what war can do the human mind. Listening to kids wanting to join the military because they 'totally are awesome at COD, which is the same thing' annoys the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. I've had many of those kids play this game, and *No spoilers* when they reach a certain point in the game they actually get really quite and stop making jokes. This is a wonderful trip into the dark side of war; the side of war we never see, or hear about. They say there are always two sides to every story; well this is the story you never hear about.   It's a beautiful mind trip into the (getting deep here yo) personal working's of the human mind, and the effects that war has on it. Very few games have actually made me feel for the consequences of my actions before. That is the sign of a game truly immersing you within itself.   A wonderful buy, perhaps a bit generic with the gameplay at times, but the story makes up for it in all ways. You owe it to yourself to play this game.

Holy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! This game was absolutely amazing. I enjoyed every minute of it, and I recommend it to everyone! I received this game through a Humble Bundle, and man, I am not disappointed whatsoever. The gameplay is on point, the story is on point, the characters are on point. You feel like you ARE the main character, Walker. And Walker is voice acted by Nolan North? Hell to the yes. The choices you have to make are brain teasing, rage inducing, and wowza! However, there is only one con, the game is extremely short, I beat it in exactly six hours. For me, that was only two sittings, but I still got very involved into the story. I felt as if I was actually there, suffering from PTSD. I picked all the choices based on what I would do in real life, and I'm not regretting anything. Amazing story! Amazing everything! Buy this immediately if you haven't already.

At first glance it looks like a generic shooter. It starts like a generic shooter.  Then it transforms to something... Different. Unique. It kicks you in the balls and doesn't let you get up.  The game reminds me Kane & Lynch: Dead Man. Both games are typical third person shooters, with self regenerating health, cover systems and dynamic camera. But their story makes them unique. What is this game about? Basicly it's a adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 'Heart of Darkness'.  It starts as a story about 3 commando soldiers on a rescue mission in Dubai. Because of misunderstanding and coincidence it turns to something much worse.  In my opinion it's a game about war crime, about sacrificing morality or humanity for accomplishing your goals. It shows how easy war can change into total massacre because of small factors. You should play SO:TL and interpret it for yourself. Graphically the game is really OK, mostly because of original location and beautiful map design.  What's really important - the game is very detailed. As our characters get deeper and deeper into Dubai conflict they are changing both physically and mentally. They're getting wounds, their equipment is getting damaged, they speak and act differently. They are even executing the enemies with more aggression and hate. Even the tips showing during the loading screens are becoming cynical. The game itself is criticising your actions, it oftens breaks the 4th wall. The shooting mechanics are good, same as the camera. I didn't have any problems with the technical aspects of the game. What makes the game even better is the soundtrack. It suits every single scene in the game, and makes me want to listen it even after the game. If you've watched 'Apocalypse Now' - you'll feel familliar.  Try it. You will get suprised, how this seemingly generic shooter is going to shock you. It's brilliant. It will definetely put your morality on a test. Like no other shooter previously.

I'm going to go ahead and say it: This is the best game ever made.  If you were to ask me about this game purely based on genre, I would tell you it's a third person shooter where a yankee comes in a foreign land and shoots people. Sounds boring and overplayed, right? That is the impression I had when I bought this game. What I found, as stated beforehand, is the best game ever made.  Sure, Grand Theft Auto V, San Andreas and the Witcher III all have large worlds to explore in and much to do. However, this game is the only one I have played up til now that is   perfect  . It is absolutely infalible.  I've just finished my first playthrough of the game, and let me tell you that this game exposes me and humiliates me simply by giving me a situation where lives hang on the line and the choice on how to act. I have been kept awake by the decisions I have made in this game and what they tell me about myself.  The blurb of this game says it's 'designed to question players' morality'.   You're damn ♥♥♥♥ing right it questioned my morality.      This   is what videogames can do that no other kind of entertainment can do:  challenge the player.  Give him responsibility and tell him to own it. I wasn't able to tell Upham to save Mellish    when he watched on in cowardice as he got stabbed,    so I felt free to trash him in frustration. I wasn't able to be mad at the dealer who shot the litle girl in Pac's 'Dopefiend's Diner', so I felt absolved from guilt. Spec Ops: The Line put up a ♥♥♥♥ing mirror to my face and said to me  you're no better than the rest of us  and it was 100% right.  To anyone who is reading this: Play this game and come back to this review.     Do you feel like a hero yet?

Do you know this feeling when there are two voices in your head arguing over what is the right thing to do and it makes you extremely uncomfortable? It's called cognitive dissonance and Spec Ops: The Line makes you take a nosedive into a sea of that feeling.   It shows war as what it is. Not as the glorified, heroic, romanticized ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that we get stuffed with from games like Call of Duty and Battlefield, but as horror, pure, unfiltered horror. If you felt like the moral choices in games like Fallout punched you in the gut, what you'll have to do in Spec Ops will leave you feel like the game punched you in the face, wrenched open your jaw, reached down your throat and ripped out your guts.  Spec Ops makes the player feel what the main character is going through, but not simply via making you identify with the character you play. Its gameplay, world design and everything makes you feel uncomfortable, nauseous and morally torn apart. It really is brilliantly crafted.  I'll stop here to avoid possible spoilers or how you perceive the game while playing, but if you feel like dropping the game after playing for an hour because the combat feels generic and/or bad, please, please don't do that and press on, it's well worth it.  There's one last thing I'll say, if you decide to play it: When you hear the line 'Because you wanted to be something you're not.', that's aimed at you, not the character you're playing.

I just finished a lenghty Spec Ops achievement marathon. Played this game a lot in my freetime and now I finally can put it to rest. While I don't want to consider myself an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥, I like to pay games I really enjoy a tribute by completing them 100%.  Now, this introduction perfectly fits (more or less) into the message of the game. Are violent games really just games, you play and get an achievement for your 50th headshot? Is it okay to sit back and enjoy war, while you are the hero, kicking the ♥♥♥ of all the terrorist scum that threatens to destroy the world? I can't really compare Spec Ops: The Line to Battlefield, Call of Duty setting-wise or Gears of War and Mass Effect gameplay-wise, as I've never played them. But what I can say is, that, in my humble opinion, Spec Ops: The Line is a masterpiece. Not without its flaws, but a masterpiece nonetheless.  Gameplaywise, you get the typical brown modern war 3rd person shooter thingy. What do you expect? You play a badass dude to murder tons of evil dudes. Simple as that. But storywise, you are encountered by some moral questions, you might not have asked you yet. And suddenly, all the dull gameplay makes sense in a more complex way.  I don't want to spoil too much here, so I'll keep it short: If you are expecting a breakthrough in modern warfare gameplay and gunfights, this game is nothing for you. If you are interested in a good and gripping story, with one ore the other twist and an underlying message, you must play this game, even if you don't care about war shooters, like me. Highly recommended!

-Quick Review-   Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter who takes a warfare story telling aspect, and mixes in gritty realism, coupled with very solid cover-based-game play.    -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:  How do you talk about the story in this game without giving away any great details? The story goes in a very unorthodox direction from most Shooter games I've played. Additionally there are choices that you make throughout the game, and it's not just 'go right or go left' as the saying goes 'indecision is a choice'. In the words of William T. Sherman we hear the well known quote 'War is Hell' To be quite honest not very many shooter games run with that concept, in Spec Ops: The Line, you will see far more gritty details of consequences of warfare... and the people effected.  As a final note regarding the story length, I after playing through the game my first time I put in 5.5 hours. I generally play slower trying to find extra items and do restarts for achievements, so that should be longer then a standard player will take to get through the game.    Game Play:  Spec Ops: the line is a cover-based third person shooter, meaning while you're being shot at you will move from cover to cover, most of the mechanics are quite straight forward, but do take some getting used too, you can jump over cover, change cover quickly by looking or pressing a movement key in that direction THEN pressing Space, there is a fair bit of learning to be had. It should be noted that the controls will take some getting used too, I had already played a few third person shooters so those old controls were messing me up while I was trying to learn the new ones. Once you learn the controls the rest of the game is quite enjoyable to play through. Even if you're unfamiliar with cover-based-shooters the starting difficulty is friendly enough that you can get the hang of it while gunning down your foes. (I would still recommend getting used to hiding behind cover)   Achievements:  There are 50 Achievements in Spec Ops: The Line, after my first play through I had 33 of those achievements, there are four achievement category types: Find the lintel (collection), Get kills or special kills with weapons, Make this choice in the story, and standard story quests.   Price  Spec Ops: The Line is priced at $29.99, by this point most people should be used to games (especially shooters) being priced there, as I always say 'I recommend waiting for a sale'.    Conclusion:  Spec Ops: The line will appeal most to people who enjoy the two qualities of 'Third person shooter', and 'story telling'. If you just want a shooter where you run in and pew pew pew, this isn't the right game for you. If you like playing games with meaningful stories, making hard ethical decisions while gaming or just looking for a change of pace this game will provide it. To quickly recap: Story - Outstanding story telling methods. Game Play - Controls might be a bit tricky at first, but the cover based combat is very good. Achievements - Pretty Standard, there are a few tricky looking achievements though. Price - Standard, wait for a sale.

Spec Ops: The Line is a towering Skyscraper among average buildings. It doesn't stray far from the typical MMS formula: lots of killing, fun but plain combat, and handholding from the AI. Where it does set its self apart, is the campaign. While not the most finely crafted narritive I have experienced, it does lend its self with a serious attitude that leaves the player pondering on the morality of their choices. As a fan of games where the story is big, evident and emotional, it hit the spot for a few hous (It only took 7 hours to complete the campaign). Although the campaign quite linear, the game often offers you choices in both the story, and in gameplay, but these choices are black and white, very little middle ground is to be had.  It is a beautiful looking game; there are many times when I was on a tall building and I looked out into the horizon, and just stayed, admiring the view. It runs well too, I was able to play it on almost all the max settings, 1080p at 60FPS with only a GTX460m.  I recomend this game to anyone who likes a good story, or is a massive fan of the MMS genre.

Wow! Simply said WOW!!! This is not your average 'America saves the world from Terror'-crap story that most military shooter bring us today. No, this is not sir, this is an engaging tale of survival amidst the 'Heart of Brightness in Dubai', exlporing themes commonly overlooked in other games of the genre. Here 'The Line' is definetely getting crossed and in the end there was never any other choice than the way we advanced to the climax.  While some players may be complaining about certain events in the game that might make you feel bad, it should make you think about war and what's going on - or better what is/may/might happen in a warzone. Thus Spec Ops The Line becomes one of those rare to find 'anti-war' titles. An arousing story that shouldn't upset us but make us think.

I've had this game for a while now and have just got to playing it, and I have to ask myself: Why have I not played this sooner?  Without spoiling anything, the story and plot are completely beautiful and heartwrenching, on the edge of your seat surprising, and will completely question your morales and those of the characters you interact and meet. I jumped in expecting another mindless shooter with loose story, but found myself in love with this game and its story.  On the technical aspect, the gameplay is relatively simple and easy. Suicide difficulty is not incredibly challenging, but a large factor of combat is to utilise your Delta squad and hide behind cover. The game can be completed in under 7 hours, probably less, which seems perfect as the story isn't drawn on and combat seems fast enough behind cover that you aren't getting entirely bored.   Graphically, I am also surprised at how beautiful this game can look. Your Delta squad continues to degrade and gain battle scars, blood, and torn clothing as the game progresses and otherwise looks like days of fighting in Dubai. The scenery and city looks amazing as well! I play with a GIGABYTE P35K-1 with nVidia GTX 765m and ran everything to the max and had no flops.  Story: 10/10 Gameplay: 6/10 Graphics: 9/10 Strength of Denial: 100/10

This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.  Why?  The gameplay is pretty standard fare for the shooter genre, with some somewhat interesting squad dynamics thrown in. I've heard the multiplayer is terrible, if you can find anyone still playing it at all.   So why is this game so amazing? The story in the campaign. It plays on your psyche, messes with your head, and makes you question why you even play games like this. It's a critique of the entire genre, one that desperately needed to be made. Why do we, as gamers, typically like to shoot things for fun? Is killing people in a video game truly harmless? If so, should we still enjoy it as much as we do?  The story draws from some classics for inspiration (most notably Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad), but it takes what it needs and expands on the rest. It takes some classic conventions, and finds a way to use that to tell its own story, and tell a completely new and fresh message.  'To kill for yourself is murder. To kill for your government is heroic. To kill for entertainment is harmless.'

To be honest with you, I just picked this game up because it was on sale. And looking at the metacritic score and the name itself I rather expected it to be another generic, mediocre shooter. Oh boy, I couldn't have been more wrong!!  Gameplaywise it totally fits that description. It is a Gears of War-esque Shooter with slightly harsher damage model. Graphics are typical PS3/Xbox360 stuff. On the other hand the Leveldesign, though linear, is well made and creates a atmospheric and breathtaking environment I often found myself starring at in appreciation.  AI is decent. Squadmates are actually useful, taking cover and supporting you. Enemy AI will use suppressive and cover fire and try to flank you and also use grenades to flush you out of cover. Not gonna talk about MP. Yager studio themself said in an interview they didn't want it and they didn't do it. But Publisher 2K still made a different studio do it and shoe-horned it in... So what is the BIG selling point of this game? It's narrative!  If 'Apocalypse Now' (and for that matter 'Heart of Darkness') was a game, this is what it would be like. You will see plenty of references and parallels but rest assured, the game isn't just a copy. It has a story in its own right and goes its own ways.  As the story unfolds the lines between good and evil will start to dissolve until there is nothing left. You are being dragged into a conflict you have no concept off and always left one step behind. It keeps spiraling out of control fast as things turn sour and ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan - mainly because of your own ignorance - while you also have to bear the dire consequences of your actions.  On the metalevel the game is toying with alot of our preconceptions about Shooters, how violence and morality is represented and going into some other really deep stuff if you start thinking about it. SpecOps deliberately keeps giving the players red herrings, false targets and vague objectives and watches us kill again and again regardlessly. It says we need to blow up some people and we do it.  Because it is what needs to be done to accomplish the mission, right? 'We have no choice' like Cpt. Walker says. After all we are the good guys, fighting for a just cause with only the best intentions. Violence is a mere necessity.  Who would have thought those people might be unarmed civilians with children? And at the next loading screen you will be asked “Do you feel like a hero yet?” That effectively is what SpecOps is all about: to ♥♥♥♥ with your head and expectations. This game is a mind ♥♥♥♥ through and through.  Bottom line: don't let yourself be put off by it's looks, because there is more to it than it first seems. You should really give it a try! Chances are you won't be disappointed.

A vailiant effort, but flawed and shows the limits of video games and how they can never be considered art.  Specs Ops: The Line has received much praise in weaving a horrific tale of an op gone wrong and the horrors of war. The game expertly puts you in the shoes of the main character as he teeters on the edge of sanity as his PTSD nightmare slowly consumes him. But in the end, the game's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness.  The game not only encourages, but actively pushes you towards making crazy 'gamer' decisions that leads to the story spiraling out of control. Executing a downed enemy is a common video game mechanic that players have come to expect. Executing a downed enemy also gives you ammo for both weapons. However, should you choose to simply double-tap them with your gun, you will not spiral into madness at the same rate as a normal playthrough. Although there are many hidden third options to most of your choices, the game doesn't let you make any key decisions that sidestep everything.  Spec Ops: The Line does a great job of telling one story but fails to give you the other option of not succumbing to monstrosity. The gameplay is very tiresome and rather boring. Some would say that this is in part of the game trying to parody the meaninglessness of your generic modern First-Person-Shooters, but was this honestly the best way of going about this? Couldn't we have some fun going down this hellish slide?  I only wish that there were more choices that we could make that would better simulate PTSD/anxiety/paranoia. Why was there no choice to interact with the civillian NPCs in a way that would test our distrust of the local populace? Why was there no option to deal with groups that were obviously armed and cutious, yet not overtly hostile?  Overall, Spec Ops: The Line is a good game to experience but not necessarily to play. I would definitely recommend this game if you enjoy storytelling experiences.

This game is one of a great game that I will strongly recommend - but not to everyone. Indeed, it is both very similar to the basic TPS and very different from the other 'common' games.   For a start, the game mechanics don't really stand out from other shooters. The cover system is quite classic, the various weapons are nothing but well-made, enemies will most likely be coming by everywhere while shooting and yelling, the different AIs are correct, although your teammates will most of the time die while running, and there are shining red barrels that will explode when shot, as well as turrets and miniguns. Multiplayer is not worth the single player, and coop consists of alternative 2-players missions. Still, there are quite some original things, such as the contextual sand that will often allow you to get rid of a bunch of angry people or some eye-candies like the trees, walls or towers that fall when shot at.  That brings us to the fact that the game also looks like a movie. Indeed, it's very linear, as the main storyline can be summed up with a map. But it's also pretty scripted, and every single detail seems to have been done with care : the crashing helos, the falling towers, the blowing glass roofs, the collapsing quicksands... and even though sometimes, the action is spoiled by the too obvious script, it still succeeds in stressing the player, who'll eventually have to choose between four pretty different endings.  But the biggest part of the game revolves around the story. It may be a little hard to get why you get shot at so much in the beginning, but except a few odd things, the struggle between morality and immorality, allies and enemies, life and death is surprisingly thorough for a videogame. Indeed, there is nothing silly, as it's not a simple confrontation between good and evil, but rather a showdown of cruelty, selfishness, and deceived ideals meant to ensure the survival of a few people - or to wipe out guilt -, even if it leads to the death of dozens of - more or less - innocent people. There is no one truly good, not even civilians, and no one truly evil, not even soldiers, and there is thus no right choice to do : whatever you do, people will die, and you only can determine who - to some extent. Indeed, you'll end up doing things totally against common sense, only because it's the only way to face the others, who are already doing crazy things : it's a shocking experience that to burn people with white phosphorus and watch them burn while speaking to a dying burnt man. The dialogues are, by the way, pretty interesting, and the characters' psychologies are really profound, as both of your two teammates will have a different position on what happened, what you've done and what to do next. The interesting part is that it's hard to tell who to follow, as no one seems to be wrong, and in the end, you'll be the main problem down there - but you won't realize it before the last few minutes.  In the end, the story can be summed up as a descent into hell of a mad soldier caught in the spiral of violence and guilt, and the whole game leads the player through sceneries of despair and desolation, all along a depressing story tainted with blood. But if that game is a masterpiece, it's also thanks to the fact that the story is complex and  insanely  hard to get, as the main character is sliding into madness - which is also hard to get to which degree until the very last moments. Thus, this game isn't suitable for everyone, as it requires to be able to use their brain while playing, so as to make choices as well as to try to understand the story so far: you simply can't play just to shoot. That game is a proof that videogame is art.  P.S. : Somehow, the game made me remember of Prayer of the Refugee, by Rise Against. Just check the lyrics :p

(semi)-SPOILERS   I get what the game was trying to do here, but for me, at least, it just doesn't work.  The game REQUIRES you to treat it like a CoD or Battlefield game, otherwise it doesn't make any sense. The plot railroads you into situations where you might logically just sit down and say 'Hey, guys, why are you shooting us? We literally haven't done anything to you.' But, hoping that the audience is used to shooters where you just shoot people for poorly explained reasons, the game just hopes you don't think for more than two seconds about what's happening.   Likewise, the fact that the character (and game)-defining moments railroad you into a 'choice' removes all feelings of personal responsibility and empathy that they spend so long building up. Call me cynical, but if you give me a game and force me to do something to progress, that has the same impact as follows: 'Hey, you literally -have- to kick that puppy to continue the story' 'Okay, I guess.' 'OH MY GOD HOW COULD YOU, YOU MONSTER' Of course, these forced 'choices' are required, because barely anyone would actually chose to do it this way if they were given the choice. Most people aren't ♥♥♥♥ing psychopaths.  BUT the story requires you to act like a psychopath in order to make sense. This lead to me, trodding along acting fairly sensibly, then the game forcing me to do something horrid, then scolding me for doing that thing that it forced me to do. There were one or two moments that actually let you choose what to do at some points, and when one of them went wrong, that was when I actually felt terrible, because it was MY choice that lead to this, and not the the plot railroading me.  I came out of this experience a bit unfufilled, really. I had acted sensibly, trying to make logical choices where I could; not killing civillians, trying to stop people from shooting me on sight, even going as far to flashbang soldiers to see if I could just get their attention for a moment. Of course, this doesn't work, because the plot demands that you kill people. Frankly, this gave me some cognitive dissonance, because, to me, it was abundantly clear that we were fighting the 'bad guys' for no reason, and yet there was no way of acting on this understanding. Then, later, the game shouts at you 'WHY DID YOU KILL ALL THESE PEOPLE?' Gee, I don't know, because you didn't give me a choice?  I almost feel as though Spec Ops plays it's hand too soon, immediately trying to make you feel guilty for the people that you were forced to kill not ten seconds ago. This results in that cognitive dissonance I mentioned earlier. I know I'm fighting these guys for no reason, and that I just killed them in a super-not-okay way, but I had to, because the plot demands it. I think the story would have made so much more sense had they acted more like a modern shooter, romanticising things like WP, or drones, biological weapons or something, and giving you the choice to use them, but tricking the players into doing so because why wouldn't you? It's way more fun, cooler and easier than having to shoot everyone yourself, right? Instead, the game actively dissuades the player from using WP, which detracts from what it's trying to do, which is trick players into becoming a psychopathic war criminal.  Compared to something like CoD or Battlefield, this game is definitely leagues ahead in terms of story. Maybe people who are really into the shooter genre might get more involved in this story, but me, coming from more RPG-esque games, where choice is commonplace, this just felt linear and annoying, because I knew what I wanted to do, but I just wasn't given the option. Still, points for trying to reverse some genre tropes and using your shooter knowledge against you.

I don't review games often but this one really smacks you in the face. When you watch a movie and you're still thinking about it days later, you know you've seen something special. I am having that same feeling with this game.  I am not a big shooter player so I won't comment in detail on the gameplay mechanics or the difficulty, I found them both great, but the story and the artwork was incredible. I found myself rationalising the protagonist's choices as if they were my own. Even as events started to spiral out of control, I found myself trying to think about what I would do if it were my boots in the sand. I couldn't ever question Walker's decisions because they were always based on a truth he had compiled from an incomplete understanding of the situation, which was something I shared with him.   It's a three dimensional look at war, imaged in breathtaking scenes and with commendable voice-acting. Oftentimes, war is not as we traditionally define it. Decisions are not always based on what is good or bad, heroic or cowardly. They are often driven by interpretation of orders and gut-feel. And when dreadful things happen, do we really fully appreciate the toll on those that felt they had to pull the trigger, squinting though the fog of war?   This is a visceral and engaging experience which I highly recommend to gamers looking for something a bit different.

Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like 'Apocalypse Now!' with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit. It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good.   I would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no 'Red Orchestra' immersion wise, but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender, which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels, which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.  The game looks fantastic, even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had 'Rainbow Six' style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a 'military shooter gone horror' vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it, kind of like the Kane & Lynch series. It was just a little too hamfisted, on rails and 'gamey' for that feeling to hit me, but I enjoyed the horrific descent into madness nonetheless. If you are looking for a solid 3rd person shooter with an intense atmosphere, definitely grab this game.   7/10

A game you will love or hate, absolutely. As a military shooter, it's a generic but functional game with a useless tacked-on multiplayer mode that the developers have openly disowned. As a story-based singleplayer experience, it's notable for taking what starts as the most generic story imaginable and turning it into a meta-narrative that questions the the nature of video games while the protagonist questions his own heroism. While not perfect in its storytelling, it tries something that flies in the face of current trends and is essentially a giant middle-finger to Call of Duty and its imitators. Either you'll be on board with the idea and enjoy its ambiguous storyline, or you'll find it a pretentious attempt at an art game built on the back of a mediocre shooter. If you're curious, it's worth the time and money simply because it exists.

'...There's a line men like us have to cross....'  Spec Ops: The Line, where do I even begin? I love this game. I love it more than Portal, more than Half Life and more than CS GO. This game is underrated and didn't get the attention that it deserved.  Graphics and Audio- This game looks really good for 2012. The environments are rich and have so much detail. You can even use your surroundings to your advantage. The models look great for both characters and weapons. The only thing that I don't like about the graphics is that some cutscenes look worse than the actual game and they seem poorly rendered. The audio is also great and has a lot of depth to it, but the audio design seems simple. What I mean is that the stronger guns sound more powerful than the weaker guns, but this doesn't bother me. 93/100  Gameplay-This game plays kinda like Gears-of-War and shares some similar mechanics. For example, when you sprint your camera gets lower and your character is slouching. Also, you can vault over cover while behind it and you can switch cover if you are looking at it. But, the gunplay is different. Each gun is designed for a different situation. For example: most shotguns are ment for close range, the ARs are ment for medium range, the SMGs are ment for close-medium range and shooting while on the move and so on. The gameplay can get annoying at time since sometimes, while your character slides into cover, he can get riddled with bullets and even get killed. This gets really annoying and even frustrating at times. 84/100  Story- I'm not going to spoil you the story because it is just amazing. Once you play through it, you might leave with some unanswered questions. This is good becuase that means that this is a game that makes you think about what happened, what you did and if you really are the Walker you think you are. Also, there is a lot of character development. First you start off with three cocky Delta operatives and through out the story, they change and by the end, they are completely different characters. The story is the best I have ever seen in a video game. 100/100  Multiplayer- The multiplayer doesn't use the story so you don't really care if you loose or not and the game modes aren't even that great. It's just gunplay here. 65/100  Final Verdict-I highly recommend this game to anyone that is tired of CoD campaigns going over the top and making you think about what you are doing. Right now this game is $30 and I think that is a fair price. The Final score is an 85.5/100, but that is with the multiplayer. If you take it out than this game becomes a 92.33./100. The second score is more accurate and if multiplayer wasn't in the game, I think $30 is still a good price. If you don't want to pay $30, you can wait a bit since I see this game on sale a lot or you can get for a great price online. The story will blow you away and make you want to play more, so give this game a try.

It's a worthwhile product.   Long story short, play it on easy difficulty and just for the story. The gameplay is used cleverly sometimes in unconventional ways. Not a masterpiece, some narrative twists are done for better drama effect even in Max Payne from 2001 by action game standards. Nothing more and nothing less than a good war drama set up in juxtaposition against 'conventional' patriotic action ones. An allure towards the nihilistic unfortunately, as it only questions and doubts without introducing anything new. It's a recycling of previous notable works as 'Apocalypse Now'.     The problem of the game is that the gameplay messes with the 'no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t' approach to traumatized human feelings.  The attempt to sarcasm Saving Private Ryan and other action war products of American culture is in conflict with the serious message on the topic of war. Breaking the 4'th wall is far too often used with questionable end result or in any cohesive message delivered. It's awesome to have Spec Ops attempt a new approach. I'm optimistically looking to the future of this message progress further. As a media, video games need more of this. However without trying to use inappropriate tools to convey those messages through achievements, hero puns.  I wasn't searching for action in the first place. Did not think it was amusing or well placed. It would also be interesting to hear arguments pro war too. Or how consistent the message was in general, without deconstructions in post modernist style. Again, a lot of weak points in the general anti war message with wide generalisation.  --------------------------------------------------------------------------  Recommended for familiarisation. This is a damn gripping narrative. It's not an overly long game and the shooter mechanics won't set the world on fire but they're solid. Get in this for the story because it's a great one. It'll stay with you. It's great when a game for more than one moments has elements that make you say 'WOOOAH'.

WTF is it? - Well, the first question that really needs to be asked is if you want to feel like **** after playing a game. If not, avoid this altogether. Why you ask? The content of The Line can be compared to that of the infamous airport mission in Modern Warfare 2. It is disturbing. However, what you get is an intense third-person shooter with a brilliant story. The combat is average and there is not much enjoyment to be had in it, this also applies to the multiplayer which is mediocre at best. What you really are paying for is the campaign which can be beat in about five hours on regular difficulty. However, those five hours are enganging and will make you ponder the horrors of war. This should come as no surprise as the story parallels that of Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad. One considering buying this should also be made aware that the ending(s), of which there are five, could dissapoint or invoke anger in some. I however thought the ending was amazing but it really is up to the person who plays through the game.  Verdict - A story-rich game that people should buy if it's on sale.  BTW - The sand in this game is plentiful.

Spec Ops: The Line is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games. It was released on 26 June 2012 in North America and 29 June 2012 internationally for Microsoft Windows, and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles. n Spec Ops: The Line, the player controls Captain Martin Walker, who is sent into a post-catastrophe Dubai with an elite Delta Force team on a reconnaissance mission, where they find dead American soldiers. Upon the finding, Walker declares that the team's mission has changed, and that they will search Dubai for survivors  Spec Ops: does so many good things right, but falls short from a masterpiece. While the game is a brilliant set-piece of PTSD and the true horrors of war, it falls short as a game in whole. While the story, soundtrack, voice acting, visuals and overall quality is amazing, it's gameplay is just so generic and boring. Nothing new will be seen here, unfourtunately. The game is a third-person cover shooter game, with no originality. The cover system and gunplay are mediocre at best, and this is a real drawback from it being an amazing experience in all sectors. But, I really don't want to get too much into such details, it's just something you've played in a hundred other games, let's focus on what's so amazing about this underrated game.  The story. It may sounds like something trivial, because people have high standards these days, amazing gameplay, amazing graphics, amazing this amazing that, you get my point. This game is narative driven game, and that's it. Multiplayer is shallow and unstatisfying, but this isn't the point of Spec Ops. It's a game that sets one goal, and one goal only. To trully showcase the  Horror  of war. War is a gruesome experience that really scars the human mind, and while me and you won't probably fight in one, this game has a trully shocking way of showing us just how brutal things can get between the gunfire. It will surely have a last impact on you, it did on me at least. The game starts pretty standard, a turret section that's pretty  bland  and  boring , nothing too over the top here. But once the game kick off, things start to get heated. We start in the shoes of Cpt. Martin Walker, voiced by Nolan North. The game starts off with you and your squad mates being sent to the new destroyed Dubai, to investigate and search for survivor, call for reinforcements and get back home. Those are your only orders, nothing more. But things get out of hand once Walker gives to order to   open fire on the enemy . This thing will become more relevant down the line, since this game has set out to question one simple thing,  Who is the enemy? . And it will teach you that thing, once you complete it.  Being developed on the Unreal 3 Engine, the games shines mostly. Dubai is a super showcase of glowing sand, vibrant interiors and a feel of depth and complexity. But it's all just a shell to hide all of the horros that lay ahead of your journey to destruction. The game will soon present to you the brutal, and extremely graphic violence of when  things get ouf of hand  when people mentally breakdown and can't tell the difference between good or evil. It's amazing, especially since this game breaks once and for all the trope that all enemy's in video games must be shot down immediatly without question, and because they are  different  or russian/middle eastern. It's superb, to be honest.   In the end, since I could talk about this game for hours and hours, even though it's a short, but it's an intense ride, and filled with guilt. Never, ever I have felt such guild after playing a videogame. Like, really. Videogames that make you feel guilty?  How is that?  One might ask. Well, it's quite easy. This game does not reward you for shooting everyone in a 100km radius at the speed of Clint Eastwood, it will break you down as fast as the protagonists. It's amazing how well the story is crafter, considering at the end of the day, it makes you feel human, it makes you question so many things. Superb. Honestly, superb.   In case you don't want to hear all of my rumbling, I will list the things that I enjoyed and disliked about this game and give it a rating.   The good    Amazing story   Superb story   Breathtaking visuals   Retroactive enviroment   Unique setting   Incredible soundtrack/voice acting   Moral and emotionally heavy    The bad    Generic gameplay   Mediocre gunplay   Short lenght   Cookie cutter multiplayer   No replay value   The cover mechanics are a bit awkward  I give this game a 8/10 rating, thanks to so many good elements in it, falling short, unfortunately to such a generic gameplay. Amazing overall nonetheless, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

Apocalypse Now: Dubai  The combat is solid enough, controls are slightly strange but entirely passable. I'm not personally a fan of games on rails but this one is a decent roller coaster ride that makes the rails a bit more acceptable for me.  Enemies react to being shot in limbs appropriately and shotguns feel great, which is honestly a rarity in games.   The game gives a lot of forced prompts for commands and actions you have to or are only capable of doing at those moments which is strange and irritating. The giant flashing prompts on the screen forcing your hand really take you out of the immersion of the story, which could be pretty good if the prompts didn't reinforce an arcade shooter feel. The cover system is done fairly well, although i found myself fighting with the controls in many instances because it's just a few slight changes from what standard shooters bring you to expect.  I have run into some instances where invisible barriers would block my shots and they threw in the generic heavily armored (Commonly known as bulldozer) type unit who can be frustrating to an extreme when most enemies react appropriately, a sticky grenade or an RPG on his facemask will do little more than break the mask off and stun him. The bare face of his still requires significant amounts of shots to kill him with any weapon despite being unarmored which means damage is based on body parts and not types of armored cover. In a shooter, this can be pretty irritating but expected from the lazier ones, so it might not bother other people as much.  Ammo can be quite scarce for you and you alone as your team mates have unlimited ammo, dreadful aim, and unlimited grenades but can only be used in designated situations or of their own personal choosing. They also pick their own cover in your general area which can occasionally put them on the wrong side of it, forcing your hand to go save them in the open during a bad enough situation to get them downed.   I haven't tried the Multiplayer or Co-Op yet so I can't comment on those.  Combat 7/10 Story 7/10 Controls 6/10 Visuals 7/10  Docking score for the excessive HUD prompts and the heavily armored Bulldozer unit because those are just lazy, especially considering the environment.  I'd have to give the game a 6/10 overall  The game is good for a few bucks, I would recommend it if you can catch it on a decent sale.

Introduction: The game takes place in an post post-apocalyptic Dubai, but what happens in the game's story rings true to every war that ever took place. Futhermore, I am sure that if a war veteran would play this game, it would be likely to trigger PTSD, due to the nature of imagery and feel that it gives.    Pros: -Really good, balanced and haunting story -Immersive environments -Choices matter  Cons: -Gameplay is slightly mundane -The multiplayer mode is just a filler   Conclusion: The game ends up being a great anti-war game that focuses on the atrocities that man is able to commit when pushed beyond limit, it's being held back a bit by the gameplay, which feels poorly ported. Nevertheless, I still highly recommend getting this game.   Rating: 9/10  Also, if you're looking for other war related quality material check out the following: 1) Joseph Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness' 2) Francis Ford Coppola's 'Apocalypse Now' 3) Terrence Malick's 'The thin red line' 4) Elem Klimov's 'Come and See' (this one's the harshest to watch) “The horror... the horror.” - Joseph Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness', also spoken by Kurtz in Apocalypse Now (1979)

Wearing the trappings of a modern military shooter, a genre that has become the industry's main enemy of creativity and thoughtful exploration of important thoughts on the hero fantasy and graphic violence, Spec Ops: The Line works its deep cover with such intensity and unflinching honesty that it demands the attention of any gamer who takes games as an art form seriously. I almost passed this one by due to its superficial premise and appearance, but I am very glad I did not.  Following in the footsteps and perfecting the ugly tenor of games like Kane & Lynch and Far Cry 2, this brutal exploration of PTSD, gaming's indulgence in violence, and the cost of war pulls no punches in challenging the player to confront what--if any--redemptive or meaningful value there is in parading through a foreign landscape as a hero of war. Forced to make ugly decisions that will demand you square with the game on an emotional level and shouted down for every mistake you will inevitably make, this is the slap in the face an industry drenched in blood and rewarded violence needs. Marking a new era in mature gaming, Spec Ops: The Line is a challenge to us to return from our thoughtless murder and enter into a new era of self-aware, meaningful interactive experiences.

This is, hands down, the best game I've played in a long time. The story is engaging and honestly took me by surprise a few times. The dialogue never feels hammy and the voice acting is spot on, which really helps you to connect with the characters and actually care about them. The controls are solid and intuitive once you learn them, though occasionally you'll find yourself sprinting past cover you meant to enter, or running into a low wall. This is a rare occurrence however and overall, I can find no other faults. Visually, Spec Ops is gorgeous, filled with brilliant camera work and great level design. I found myself stopping to gawp at the scenery numerous times. Later in the game, there are a few moments that really stand out visually and add to the narrative perfectly. Death never felt like a chore in this game, either. In some games death can put you off playing but with Spec Ops, this isn't the case. Instead I felt myself compelled to learn from my mistakes and try again and again to storm that machine gun nest or fight down another bloodsoaked patch of sand in search of the mysterious Colonel Konrad. This game is well worth the money, the action is intense, the gameplay is well balanced and the difficulty curve is just steep enough to keep you feeling engaged all the way through.

Apocalypse Now: Dubai  The combat is solid enough, controls are slightly strange but entirely passable. I'm not personally a fan of games on rails but this one is a decent roller coaster ride that makes the rails a bit more acceptable for me.  Enemies react to being shot in limbs appropriately and shotguns feel great, which is honestly a rarity in games.   The game gives a lot of forced prompts for commands and actions you have to or are only capable of doing at those moments which is strange and irritating. The giant flashing prompts on the screen forcing your hand really take you out of the immersion of the story, which could be pretty good if the prompts didn't reinforce an arcade shooter feel. The cover system is done fairly well, although i found myself fighting with the controls in many instances because it's just a few slight changes from what standard shooters bring you to expect.  I have run into some instances where invisible barriers would block my shots and they threw in the generic heavily armored (Commonly known as bulldozer) type unit who can be frustrating to an extreme when most enemies react appropriately, a sticky grenade or an RPG on his facemask will do little more than break the mask off and stun him. The bare face of his still requires significant amounts of shots to kill him with any weapon despite being unarmored which means damage is based on body parts and not types of armored cover. In a shooter, this can be pretty irritating but expected from the lazier ones, so it might not bother other people as much.  Ammo can be quite scarce for you and you alone as your team mates have unlimited ammo, dreadful aim, and unlimited grenades but can only be used in designated situations or of their own personal choosing. They also pick their own cover in your general area which can occasionally put them on the wrong side of it, forcing your hand to go save them in the open during a bad enough situation to get them downed.   I haven't tried the Multiplayer or Co-Op yet so I can't comment on those.  Combat 7/10 Story 7/10 Controls 6/10 Visuals 7/10  Docking score for the excessive HUD prompts and the heavily armored Bulldozer unit because those are just lazy, especially considering the environment.  I'd have to give the game a 6/10 overall  The game is good for a few bucks, I would recommend it if you can catch it on a decent sale.

CAMPAIGN REVIEW  This might just be one of the best games I've ever played.  This title is to games, what Shutter Island is to movies. You might think you know what's up, and for all I know you actually know what's happening. I finnished the game in about 4 hours, but I could probably have done it faster. That kind of never happens). I'd easily recommend this game to anyone, perhaps not if you're up for a mindless killing spree though. It's a fast paced title, there's really never any 'downtime', and if you start playing it late night. You should continue until you've finnished the game, due to it's duration you might find yourself doing the last 20 minutes if you split it up into two sittings. I strongly recommend not doing that, the plot and the story is way to intricate so you can't really afford not remembering something when you boot it up the next day.  Prepare to fight for what you believe in, or atleast what you think you believe in. Prepare to question yourself, and every single action you make. Prepare to wonder whether or not you're actually a 'good guy' or if you're infact part of the problem. Prepare... To cross the line

Well, I finished this game almost at once, so we can kinda say it sucked me in. Let's start with a little summary of the game.  Spec Ops: The Line is a rather linear TPS with a couple of places you can make your own decision between ♥♥♥♥, and even bigger ♥♥♥♥. And you'll feel ♥♥♥♥ in the end.   The story: Delta Force sent to Dubai for a recon mission that quickly turns into a rescue mission, then into a 'shoot everything that moves' mission. It gets confusing at times, but the end (which I won't spoil you) helps. It's...not what you'd expect. You start out as your standard US Soldier shooter with the grizzled veterans shouting commands, shooting baddies, being badass, but that quickly turns around. You are just a piece of the chess game of the forces behind the scenes. To give credit to the game, the story of Dubai getting hit by sandstorms, and getting Fallout'd is rather cool. And the visuals match, but bit later about that. Through the game I felt I was playing a TV series. Heck, it'd make a bloody good mini-series - about 6 episodes or so. The characters are good, and while not overdetailed, they do their job. And when I finished it, I felt like after a good TV show or movie. It left satisfied, but somehow empty.  The conversions are awesome. I had a few laughs, but the interactions between the characters never went over the top, and kept me interested throughout the story. Nobody felt flat or uninteresting, so that's a pretty good thing too. Overall, 8/10. I had little to no expectations, but left with something I won't forget soon.  Gameplay: It's a rather standard TPS with a decent selection of firearms. You get Assault Rifles, Shotguns, Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, and so forth. Most of them has a secondary mode, which is to say switch the sniper rifle's zoom (from 8x to 16x), or put a sound suppressor to the M4A1. It's fun, and while the diversity forces you to either be a really accurate shooter, or switch your weapons frequently. Ammo boxes scattered around the maps help you. The cover system while sometimes tad awkward, is good. Made me think of Mass Effect.  In every section you can find pieces of intels - a great way for knowing the backstory a bit better, and adds to the overall feel to the game. You'll be more disturbed after you find them fo' sure. Sometimes they are at obvious places, but you gotta look for the to find all. The game is rather linear, but with a game like this, it's not much of a problem. I wouldn't list this as a pro, but neither as a con. It's just linear and that's it.  7/10 - you'll remember the game for the story, as the gameplay is, while rather flowing, brings nothing new.  The visuals: Like in my Sleeping Dogs review (which you probably haven't read, but I like to mention my other written stuffs), I have to state I don't have the full specifics to play the game on High graphics. I went with medium, and it ran with about 30 fps. For me, it's solid, and the game, while not gorgeous, it looked good. The Sandstorm'd Dubai (which is almost Darude, but let's stay away from memes for a second) looks good. It's pretty detailed, and I never got bored of the environment. It wasn't exactly the same as far as I recall, and fighting on the top of a skyscraper is a nice change after eating sand on ground level. It matched the game, so I'm fine with it as is. Overall a 8/10.  Sounds: Okay, this is awesome. The mad DJ with the hits of the 80s that he plays seemingly random, the ambient music, and the OST for the game is AWESOME. Fitting, believable, and you'll feel that it gives a lot to the game. You'll eventually search for the OST on Youtube, and save it to listen later. It's really good. Kudos to the composer. 10/10  Overall I'd give this game a 8.5 out of 10, totally worth playing, and totally worth your money. Be aware of the graphic images of gore, death, and the feeling of emptiness and guilt after you've finished the game, regardless of your choices.

Not many games, or any forms of media, generally touch on self rationalization, justification, and cognitive dissonance. Not many games have 4th wall breaks in the loading screens, constantly taunting the player. Not many games use their art style to reflect the character's situation, as opposed to blatantly stating how a player feels. While it is worth a play just for a story, I do have trouble recommending that story. Even on the highest initially available difficulty, I still completed the game in 6 hours. Well, I finished this game almost at once, so we can kinda say it sucked me in. Let's start with a little summary of the game.  Spec Ops: The Line is a rather linear TPS with a couple of places you can make your own decision between ♥♥♥♥, and even bigger ♥♥♥♥. And you'll feel ♥♥♥♥ in the end.   The story: Delta Force sent to Dubai for a recon mission that quickly turns into a rescue mission, then into a 'shoot everything that moves' mission. It gets confusing at times, but the end (which I won't spoil you) helps. It's...not what you'd expect. You start out as your standard US Soldier shooter with the grizzled veterans shouting commands, shooting baddies, being badass, but that quickly turns around. You are just a piece of the chess game of the forces behind the scenes. To give credit to the game, the story of Dubai getting hit by sandstorms, and getting Fallout'd is rather cool. And the visuals match, but bit later about that. Through the game I felt I was playing a TV series. Heck, it'd make a bloody good mini-series - about 6 episodes or so. The characters are good, and while not overdetailed, they do their job. And when I finished it, I felt like after a good TV show or movie. It left satisfied, but somehow empty.  The conversions are awesome. I had a few laughs, but the interactions between the characters never went over the top, and kept me interested throughout the story. Nobody felt flat or uninteresting, so that's a pretty good thing too. Overall, 8/10. I had little to no expectations, but left with something I won't forget soon.  Gameplay: It's a rather standard TPS with a decent selection of firearms. You get Assault Rifles, Shotguns, Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, and so forth. Most of them has a secondary mode, which is to say switch the sniper rifle's zoom (from 8x to 16x), or put a sound suppressor to the M4A1. It's fun, and while the diversity forces you to either be a really accurate shooter, or switch your weapons frequently. Ammo boxes scattered around the maps help you. The cover system while sometimes tad awkward, is good. Made me think of Mass Effect.  In every section you can find pieces of intels - a great way for knowing the backstory a bit better, and adds to the overall feel to the game. You'll be more disturbed after you find them fo' sure. Sometimes they are at obvious places, but you gotta look for the to find all. The game is rather linear, but with a game like this, it's not much of a problem. I wouldn't list this as a pro, but neither as a con. It's just linear and that's it.  7/10 - you'll remember the game for the story, as the gameplay is, while rather flowing, brings nothing new.  The visuals: Like in my Sleeping Dogs review (which you probably haven't read, but I like to mention my other written stuffs), I have to state I don't have the full specifics to play the game on High graphics. I went with medium, and it ran with about 30 fps. For me, it's solid, and the game, while not gorgeous, it looked good. The Sandstorm'd Dubai (which is almost Darude, but let's stay away from memes for a second) looks good. It's pretty detailed, and I never got bored of the environment. It wasn't exactly the same as far as I recall, and fighting on the top of a skyscraper is a nice change after eating sand on ground level. It matched the game, so I'm fine with it as is. Overall a 8/10.  Sounds: Okay, this is awesome. The mad DJ with the hits of the 80s that he plays seemingly random, the ambient music, and the OST for the game is AWESOME. Fitting, believable, and you'll feel that it gives a lot to the game. You'll eventually search for the OST on Youtube, and save it to listen later. It's really good. Kudos to the composer. 10/10  Overall I'd give this game a 8.5 out of 10, totally worth playing, and totally worth your money. Be aware of the graphic images of gore, death, and the feeling of emptiness and guilt after you've finished the game, regardless of your choices.

This is an absolutely incredible game. Avoid it like the plague if you just want a CoD or Battlefield style game to sit down and relax, but if your grew out of that mold and out of that phase, consider this title.  10/10 Yadda yadda... The good:  Buy it now if you like a narrative driven game that challenges your preconceptions of a war shooter and the war shooter genre in general, and in one swift stroke will help you meditate on the pursuit and immediacy of gaming in one that chides you for following the core mechanic behind the choices you make but may not entirely be responsible for. It is also about how the consequences of your actions may not accurately reflect your decision-making process. Yes, this game is a brutal mind♥♥♥♥ of war, gaming, and free will in a manner that only this genre and this medium can deliver. I fully recommend Yahtzee's Zero Punctuation review as well as it is far more contemplative than the usual satire but just as pithy.  Still 10/10 but The Not-so-good:  OTOH, it's not without its faults. You'll find yourself in a beautifully designed world with, at times, clunky gameplay that drives a wedge between the player and the experience. For example, I had to restart far too many checkpoints due to the absurd amount of enemies (while on medium difficulty, mind you) that spawn at times where I found myself overwhelmed by the 'enemy' and a lack of ammo. At these junctures, the game has a bad habit of recommending you downgrade to Baby's 1st FPS mode since you're dying so much, but even worse is the fact that I had to so I could move on once or twice. Not the perfect cover-based shooting system, or shooting system if we're honest, but nothing that will break the deal. Also, it relies far too much on hordes of baddies including Heavies and snipers and turret gun setpieces. I found these a bit tedious, to be honest.  On the whole, it's a shame this is the game that pretty much bankrupted the studio because it's a good bet that it will be fondly remembered in gaming history as a shining example of lovingly crafted storytelling and hailed as one of the best. It will also give you nightmares.

Spec Ops: The Line is set in a war torn Dubai in the aftermath of an unprecedented sandstorm that left the city engulfed in sand. You take up the role of Captain Martin Walker, leader of a Delta team alongside Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo. Together, you've been sent to Dubai after a strange radio transmission was reported and your objective is to search for any remaining survivors. Dubai, (meant to be completely uninhabited after the sandstorm) is discovered to home many civillians and the group known as the 33rd. As the story progresses, you discover that the 33rd are not who they were thought to be and with that, you're forced to go through many different moral choices to help decide the fate of Dubai and your squad. By the end of the game though, everything isn't what it seems and you discover who the true enemy really is and it will leave you wanting more.  TL;DR Edition:  Pros: +Shooting mechanics are fun and simple to use +Squad members actually help out in fights, when compared to other games +Amazing Story +Had to Google what the ending meant  Cons: -Most decisions decided in the game doesn't really affect the ending -Once you die, you cannot be revived, unlike your squad members  5/5 - One of greatest story's I've witnessed in a game.

I thought this game would start off on a high note; one that would get me fired up and ready to take on the challenge set before me. I thought I would enter the world of post-apocalyptic Dubai ready for anything. But I didn't.  I thought that I would feel satisfied every time I landed a well-aimed headshot, like in CSGO. But I didn't.  I thouht I would save the civilians and kill only those who stood in the way of what was truly right. But I didn't.  I dropped white phosphorus on the civilians I was trying to save. Those men I killed with a well-aimed headshot were the true heroes. I was the villian. Anyone who wants to know what the world of war which video games have created is really like: play this game. Next to Portal 2, this is the second game to ever make me shed a tear. But this time it was for the complete opposite reason. The story was incredible.  Issues with the gameplay only lie in the fact that they were unorthodox and strange, but after an hour or two I had mastered them. Still a bit fiddly at times, though.   The graphics and visuals were great. I truly believed I was in a ruined Dubai. Even when it's destroyed and uninhabitable, the place still blew my mind. Occasionally some of the player textures would sporatically change resolution; they would look life-like one second and then potato the next, all having to do with the angle at which they were viewed. The anisotropic filtering became a noticable annoyance in some cutscenes. But even then, it was a beyond passable overall experience. Someone poured a lot of time in making it as good as possible; this much is evident, even with a few minor hiccups.   8.5/10 I hereby declare this game to be a 'must-play.' And as of the time of writing this, it is on sale for 80% off. Why the hell haven't you bought it yet?

This game. This game! This is how a shooter is supposed to be made. Engaging characters and story, excellent gun-fighting and gameplay, and a twist that made me sick with disgust at myself and Captain Walker. I loved it! After the half-way point, things go to $#!t. A spiral of madness and death opens up that you walk to the end. Even the loading screens after Chapter 10 or so start to take the ♥♥♥♥ out of you by passive-agressively insulting all you've done in the game when you're reloading after being killed. Plus, unlike most shooters, it has multiple endings depending on the choices you make!  This game is a must for fans of shooters, horror, and war games. At only $20, this game is a better deal than any CoD or Modern Warfare game out on the market. It has replay value, fun gameplay such as zip-lining, commanding your troops to snipe or bomb enemies, and interesting enviroment kills such as the standard 'shooting fuel tanks to make them explode' but also a new 'shoot out glass to drop sand and stun enemies.' It has numerous weapons, and while ammo is sometimes hard to come across, the enemies drop weapons with each one you kill, so you can their bodies. You can only carry 2 guns at a time, but this doesn't take much away from the game, giving you incentive to try out the various firearms and find the ones you like best. My only real complaint gameplay wise is that the Sticky Grenade can be more trouble than it's worth, as it has a smaller explosion range and distance to be thrown than a Flash Bang or Frag, and no bounce. It is fun to stick them onto a foe and watch them flail around, though. As for the characters, Spec Ops makes you sympathise with all of them. Even the villains have understandable motivations, and you wonder if you'd act any differently in this situation. Captain Walker, Lieutenant Adams, and Sergeant Lugo are people, with feelings and emotions that they display through both cutscenes and in-game banter. They are far superior to the burly, no-name, buzz-cut scrubs of the current FPS.  This game gripped me like no other. I got it (from a friend) on March 1st. It is now March 4th, and I have been playing almost non-stop to finish it. I had to see the ending. I had to experience what was the culmination of Captain Walker's actions and struggles. I had to. This game is the most engaging thing I've played all year, and I'd argue it is going to be an all-time favorite, right up there with the other games of my childhood I remember fondly. With FPS's pedalling boring stories, gameplay and characters that are little more than cardboard cutouts, Spec Ops: The Line makes me hopeful for the future of gaming, and sick to my stomach for the in-game atrocities I witnessed and committed. You want a good game? Buy this one.

I won't say more because I really don't want to spoil anything but let me just say this: I don't feel good having beaten this game. And I like that.  The Characters are standard military characters. That's not necessarily a bad thing though. In fact the story and presentation wouldn't work without Sgt. Lugo and Adams being the way they are.  As far as gameplay goes I consider it decent. I have played better third person shooters, I have played worse. It's fun as well as fairly well executed and that's enough for me. Some problems with the controls as mentioned above but it works. I kept getting into cover when I didn't mean to but I got used to it. You can give your two companions simple orders (Shoot that guy, throw a stun grenade or heal the other guy). They will act pretty smart on their own though. I rarely had them die on me and they took out enemies without me ordering it. The shooting is fine although I did find picking up weapons, ammo or grenades a bit clunky at times (Once again due to the them being mapped to the same button which is also used for reloading).  All things considered I would definitely recommend this game. Mostly for the experience it provides. Do you want a shooter that takes a different approach as far as storytelling goes? Then go ahead and play Spec Ops: The Line.

This isn't a generic shooter. No. Instead, this game shows war in its true colors. No super soldiers, beyond good and evil, no nobel motivations, but just a man, lost inside himself. How far your convictions can be trusted? Does 'doing the right things' justify your acts? When I finished this game, the only thing that came to my head was Guernica's paint, from Picasso. It's art, developed in form of a game, expressing all suffer and pain that only war can bring, just like Picasso did. Just insanity, death and no honor. This is how war works, this is how it is. Like everyone else who tries to justify it, ' it takes a strong man to deny what is right in front of him... ﻿'.  So, ' do you even remember why you came here? '.

For as much as Spec Ops: The Line does exceedingly well it failed in one very key area: gameplay. That combined with questionable marketing and tacked on multiplayer doomed this gem to be a commercial flop.  But what a gem it is underneath that fatal flaw. You'll be hard pressed to find a better story in the video game genre, particularly among shooters. At numerous points throughout the game I found myself stopping to simply admire the scenery. The voice acting, motion capture and script were all impressive. The audio, too, caught my attention in a positive way with some engrossing sound effects (I could practically feel the buffeting winds of the game's sandstorms) and a killer soundtrack that is creatively woven into the narrative with the Radioman character.  I don't want to give any plot points away but let me caution that this is a dark, twisted journey that is not for the faint of heart. And you won't be just a spectator throughout. You'll be forced to make decisions that stain your conscience and leave you wondering where the line between good and evil is.  There are some interesting articles out there commenting on how the gameplay was purposely made to be a distasteful slog through a seemly endless supply of faceless enemies. This is meant to impress upon the player that war isn't fun and that a killer's rationalizing mindset ('I had to do it') may be easier to arrive at than we realize. As much as I respect the effort to add depth with this kind of game design, I think that good gameplay is too important to compromise for the sake of making a point that many people won't even notice.  Before closing I'd like to note that this is a fairly short game. My total playtime for 2 playthroughs and unlocking 48/50 achievements was 12 hours. Roughly 6-7 hours first time on normal difficulty, 2 hours on achievements and 3-4 hours playing it again on easy just for the story. I didn't touch the multiplayer.  While the average score for Spec Ops: The Line is not very impressive I strongly recommend looking passed that. It is a game worth experiencing, one that I won't soon forget and one of the better games I've played in recent years.

Notice: Skip to the bottom after P&C for TL;DR.   Pros:   - Excellent story - Realistic character development - The power of choice is very strong in each decision you make - Graphics are pretty, although I WAS running on high, so take that as you will - Enviroments are amazing; fits the setting like a glove  Cons:  - Sort of clunky controls, specially on PC - If you're into that sort of thing, a run through the game's normal mode will take no more than 7 hours - If you're looking for a shooter to have fun in, this is not the game you should be playing. Go play TF2 or even CoD. - Extremely graphic content; this is truly a game that lives up to its 17+ rating  --------------------------------------  This is a story about war. Not CoD war, not Battlefield war - not romaticised war at all. This is war and suffering at its most brutal and disturbing.What I said about graphic content isn't putting it lightly at all - you WILL see things that will take you right out of your comfort zone and just smash your assumptions. This game makes fun of generic war shooters and gets away with it. It makes fun of itself sometimes. What it doesn't make fun of is war.   This is not a game you're going to leave with a smile on your face.  This is a game that will educate you.  --------------------------------------  TL;DR: If you want a game about war that doesn't make fun out of war - if you want a totally different game - this game is for you. Those who don't like heavy stories in their shooters and just want fun shooting should stay away.
