legit reviews of this game will point out that the controls are borked half the time. this is very true. You'll not vault over stuff you think you can one second only to have it let you a second later. you'll come runing out of cover in the wrong direction. etc.  On the otherhand the AI in Spec Ops is very well crafted. enemy soldiers will flank you, box you in, then throw some grenades at you for good measure. It'll drive you into moving around the field, ducking between cover, not because you feel like it, but because staying in one place for to long is a sure way to start again from a checkpoint. What the enemy has at it's disposal is just as true for your AI squadmates. who while without order will be just good anough that they dont feel like meat shields or window dressing. Once you give them an order though they'll flank, use multiple guns and grenades dynamically as the situation calls for it. Many a time i've issued orders and recieved blessed suppressing fire or a perfectly chucked grenade. While the team order mechanic isn't used anough at story beats to reinforce how inportant / useful they are if you're reading this take note.  That story, when you start piecing it together, holy ♥♥♥♥, like playing through a modernized Apocalypse Now. It'll start out as a BRO shooter; you'll get achievements, the game will slow down when you get a headshot, the characters will make funny comments after a particularly brutal hand to hand execution. Then the game takes a turn, the jokes become dryer, the deaths start feeling uncomfortably icky. Later, as the game starts its slow moral mind scramble mechanics in Spec Ops, like executions, that give you extra ammo, trap you into the BRO shooter rhythm that it's so craftily critiquing.    TL;DR Version Game is good. Like Telltale Walking Dead worth of sad with Better Guns!

I bought Spec Ops: The Line for PC when it was $2.49 during the Summer Sale. I heard that the story was great, but all I thought of it was just another time-killer while I waited for TF2 to un-screw itself.   Man oh man.  -This is in my top ten game list in terms of storyline, and has (imho) BY FAR the best plot twists in all of entertainment, right up there with The Sixth Sense and Se7en.   -The voice acting is immersive as hell. You start out the game as just a squad of soldiers, with comm chatter like 'Enemy neutralized.' As the game progresses and the toll starts to wear on both you and the characters, the interactions become more and more desperate. Walker screams, 'KILL....IS F***ING CONFIRMED.'  -The game plays more like a movie, with an unbelievable immersion factor. I would recommend playing it on Easy mode and just experiencing it.  You'll notice that I only have 5.3 hours on this game. That is the time it took me to beat the campaign, and I never want to play this game again. You know the game is working when you get a feeling of dread, a knot in your stomach that makes you realize the gravity of your decisions. For that reason, I will never play through the campaign again. One playthrough is enough to make me rethink war and its consequences. I HIGHLY recommend that you buy this, sit back, and prepare to lose your sanity.

Visually the game is very nice, good character models, very nice atmospheric & particle effects ensure that firefights get very intense. The levels are very detailed, although as typical in these games, it is not an open field, you are basically guided through a fixed path. That said, in some arena based areas you do have a choice of which way to tackle a situation.  Lots of weapons to choose from, meaning you can always look around for your favourites and alter your play style based on what you are using. Your team mates have reasonable AI, which doesn't hinder you as you play. I did not try playing MP, so my opinion is purely based on the SP campaign.  So all in all, a very good game, and worthy of your time. Please don't disregard this game based purely on the fact that it seems like 'another military cover based shooter'. The story draws you in, and gets progressively stranger as time goes on, and is definitely not just a 'by the numbers, kill the bad guy' scenario. Again, without giving away any part of the story, the game also has replay value, I will be going back to this one.

Masquerading as your generic everyday military shooter, The Line is a commendable attempt to criticize the morality of video games and other forms of escapist entertainment and the self-deluding mindset gamers often possess towards their actions. Well, 'criticize' might not be the right word to use - it really is a full-blown attack that doesn't pull any punches at any point. It's not subtle, and it misses its mark as often as it hits it, but it's honest and uncompromising in a way that's extremely rare in mainstream video games.  Even if you are turned off by the game's tone, dodgy combat and linearity, bear with it all the way to the end. While it does indulge in vagueness for vagueness' sake and many scenes may be fairly preachy, it's still much, much smarter than it first appears. The Line is a very unusual thing - a mainstream video game that doesn't seek to entertain you or make you feel good about yourself and truly exists only for the sake of its artistic ambitions. Regardless of how well it succeeds in realizing them, such an effort is worth recognition.

Spec Ops would likely be regarded as a fairly average 3rd-person cover-based shooter in a world that's already inundated with the genre, if raw gameplay were the only factor. The real draw is the decidedly grim and muddled story, which isn't quite Apocalypse Now: The Video Game, but it's still surprising that the game got made at all. Each mission strings the player along to a series of choices, simple to execute but damning in consequence. These crucial moments feel organic, urgent, unlike other games that freeze the action and give you a button prompt that basically says 'Shoot this guy, or don't.' Spec Ops is worth playing just to witness these threads come together, and the characters' responsiveness to their bad situation as it continues to worsen. I hope more games incorporate this kind of storytelling in the future.

Spec Ops: The Line is not an open world game in the vein of GTA, nor does it follow the path of Alpha Protocol or Mass Effect in offering a more linear experience that nevertheless changes based on your decisions as a player character. Spec Ops offers you some options over the course of playing it, but the game rarely signposts the choices, or tells you straight out what it will mean, or if there was a decision you could have made differently to change a later circumstance. The game setting is brilliant, even the loading screens have meaning, and the level of detail put into the way your character looks and moves and speaks contributes further to one of the most powerful and best integrated narratives in gaming. Many games *have* a story, something that happens in between you shooting people. In Spec Ops, as the game nears its end, the fact that you're continuing to play it becomes a part of the narrative it creates.

I’m not a “VIDEO games” person but a “video GAMES” one. You won’t see me praising a game like Heavy Rain because of its dull gameplay mechanics, neither over-crediting it for its TV movie-quality plot, what you would read from me about Telltale’s The Walking Dead series is that they are good interactive movies, perhaps calling them good “games” would be hard for me. But this one, this one it’s a bold act of rebellion, even when the game itself is nothing impressive, it is one of those few cases where I'm inclined to recommend a game I didn't enjoyed a lot playing to.  Spec Ops: The Line should be played, it deserves to be played, at least to experience what it does well and how it was a failed but respectable attempt to make a AAA game with an actually adult narrative and distancing itself from the cheap “play this to feel more mature” trend on gaming narrative that started more or less a couple of years after the 7th generation of consoles.   The GAME  In Spec Ops: The Line you won’t find a hidden gem with terrific mechanics, in fact, the game feels like a tasteless Gears of War clone, it feels like the genre of the game was chosen just to appeal to a bigger audience, if they had developed a top-down shooter or a strategy game a la “XCOM: Enemy Unknown” they would had saved a considerable amount of money, and even been able to invest more on its gameplay and get more or less the same sales they got (roughly 1.13M according to VGChartz).  This doesn’t mean the game is horrible, in fact, It’s decent, and even good at times, it isn’t boring and it’s A.I. isn’t bad, for example, in the hardest difficulty (which is the only one I played), it also has a fresh level design which helps to bring variety to the experience, using verticality pretty more often than third and first person shooters regularly do. So, in short, the game is not painful to play, but it isn’t also memorable gameplay-wise and you will feel no need to replay it.   The Portrait  One of the three things this game does right, and the first of them you will notice, is its environment, the ashes of Dubai are real, and not because the game is ridiculously photorealistic (which is not), but because it’s meant to communicate something, not a feeling, not a direct message, but a story, you know something more than a sandstorm happened there. The devastation and helplessness, the man-made disaster over the implacable overtaking of nature against a metropolis turning it into a no man’s land are tangible.   The designers did a good job (most of the time) trying to immerse the player by mixing the “COVER HERE PLOX” structures among the rest of the environment and they try to constantly draw the players towards what is left of the civilization to give us a break from the sand. The people designing its environment probable spent most of the time guessing: What would people do if “this” happened? The environment results believable and satisfying to watch too.  The Chant  The sound effects are decent and the voice acting accomplishes what it’s meant for. What the game does well is the music, instead of using an over the top generic film soundtrack, the game uses a soundtrack of rock music and its specter of derived genres, constantly portraying what is happening in front of you, sometimes even with some bit of irony, most of it has heavy feelings and a couple of tracks which could be considered as portraying an 'angry' or 'desperate' feeling, it counts with names as Nine Inch Nails, Deep Purple and Jimmy Hendrix.  The music also lets the sound effects of the sandstorms, broken glasses and guns take the main role when it’s needed. The radio signals also play an important role in the immersion and are a nice way of telling us what’s happening instead of leaving such task in its entirety to the cut-scenes.  Another interesting part related to the story is what I would consider as a 'cliche' being used many, many times in games to tell us the 'background' of the story, is the way of letting us get into the story by finding some intel recordings through the map, which may I say there is nothing bad with it, mostly because it's related to an already interesting story, but it's just another 'checklist' type of feature, similar to its completely unnecessary multiplayer.  The Book  The story of Spec Ops: The Line is based in a classic war novel called “Hearth of Darkness” written by the Polish Author Joseph Conrad (something the writers of this game don't try to hide) and they let you know that in the first moments of the game (I highly recommend the book, ONCE you have played the game).  The story revolves around the 33rd Battalion, a combat unit sent to help Dubai’s citizens to evacuate after a series of sandstorms downplayed or ignored by the high class and politicians of the city turned it into remnants of what it was. The 33rd was thought lost, but suddenly the US Government gets a looped message from the Colonel John Konrad about the situation of the city and the failure of its mission.   The game starts with the three-man operative from the Special Forces Delta conformed Martin Walker, John Lugo and Alphanso Adams entering to Dubai and trying to find what happened to the 33rd. The game has some twists, moral decisions, and many hard moments, it portrays war as what it is: murder, and a side trying to conquer the other, while its portrayal of the “occupation” is way lighter than how the book is based on portrays colonization, it’s very admirable to have people getting out of the safe-zone of bro-patriotic-BS found in most AAA war games, with silly “good vs. bad” plots. While it doesn’t goes deep about the political causes of a conflict, it’s a reminder of how distorted a leader’s mind can be and/or how harmful can people be by justifying their narcissistic needs by making up “the enemy” as “the evil” as an excuse for the urge to fight that “evil” which isn’t more than a result of our a need to rationalize the actions we commit or condone, probably our only scapegoat as simple mortals in one of the sides; a way of finding inner peace, perhaps full of emptiness, but enough to let us believe our own lie. First let’s take action; justification can come later as corpses can’t reply anyway. We are all heroes.  Score: 60/100.

Spec Ops: The Line is an example of an FPS done right. Mechanically this game is an average cover based shooter, however where Spec Ops shines is in it's story. The game tackles war in a very different way to other modern day first person shooters, and instead of glorifying it, the game instead focuses on the horrors of war, and the affect it has on a person.   Unfortunately my major gripe with this game is the cover system and controls, firstly the button to take cover is also bound to the same key as sprint, I died countless times as I was trying to sprint and ended up taking cover in a completely inconvenient place, in full view of the enemy. Secondly the controls feel like they were made to fit a game-pad, there are buttons like the spacebar which do 3 different things, even though there are a plethora of keys on a keyboard, and the worst part is whatever key you bind these actions to, it will always have three actions associated with it.   However despite these small inconvience's I still feel like Spec Ops is worth picking up, especially when if it goes on sale. With it's interesting characters, and exciting story, Spec Ops easily outshines it competitors.

This is, by far, one of my favorite military shooters to date. While it has some issues, I think the story more than makes up for it.  The bad parts will be much easier to get out of the way... The controls. I'm not going to lie, they are pretty horrible. They're clunky and at times unresponsive. I can't tell you how many times I died because of these issues. Next would be the typical fight, wash, repeat set up to battles. It's all worth it in the end, but it really can try your patience getting through the game.  Now for the good part, and honestly it's just one thing for me... The story. The story in this game is amazing. It's something that actually makes you think. It's not your typical, 'OH NOES THE RUSSIANS ARE ATTACKING! We're the good guys and we must protect everything!' All of this while you are mowing down countless people without second thought and blowing everything up in your wake. This makes you think about what the soldiers are actually doing, the decisions they have to make, the repercussions of those choices, how they have to deal with it. It's honestly amazing. I feel like I'm one of the few people that could care less about multiplayer in a game, just give me a game that has a good story that I can sink some time into and I will be happy. Don't devote everything to making a good multiplayer experience.  Another plus, the game looks really good. I was honestly surprised to see it was running on Unreal. The majority of the time with games on the Unreal engine, the characters look like steroid induced monsters. These people look normal and the environment is beautiful.  If you haven't bought this game already, do it. You won't be disappointed. Especially if you're a person who enjoys a game with story instead of just mindless destruction and killing.

I won't recap or try to give any deeper analysis of the game than any of the other deep reviews on here. All I can say is that I've not yet been able to replay this game the way I've replayed othe FPSs such as Operation Flashpoint Red River, COd and etc.   You find yourself getting drawn into the story in albeit subtle, but much deeper ways than you would in most other story driven games. Most 'choices determine outcome' based games allow you to choose between a clearly good option and a clearly bad option. That's mostly designed to provide replay value by way of multiple possible endings. This game puts you in the harsh, and almost nightmarish reality that sometimes there are no good outcomes. In a way I feel that this games is much needed dose of reality in a time popular partiotism, and the glossy marketing veneer that has been placed on war. Over the last 12-13 years we've been conditioned to believe that if you're anti-war then you're simultaneously anti-veteran and anti-american. This games showcases the true cost of war. It reminds us that every soldier who has seen combat comes home wounded, and that not all wounds are visible.  The moment that truly got to me was the white-phosporus scene. One part in particular, which I won't describe so as not to spoil the game, made me put the controller down and walk away from the game for at least 10 minutes to compose myself. The graphic nature of the scene wasn't any more gory than Resident Evil or simular games, but the loss it depicted was horrific to say the least. I've never seen that level of realism in any game of any genre.

If you are looking at this game because someone told you that it has a great storyline, they are absolutely right! Every scene makes you question your motives, and the dreadfully terrifying decisions that you make will leave you in tears. GET THIS GAME! Although the game has several cutscenes that are pre-rendered 30fps videos, this game has a fantastic ending, compelling story, excellent combat, and incredibly interesting characters!

What is there to say about this game?  In fact, nearly every information is spoiling a bit of this unique experience. So I have to reduce this a bit.  The Gameplay is nothing special. Sometimes there were problems with the controls but this didn't lead to big issues.  The graphics are exactly what you expect from the unreal engine 3. Not the huge improved Unreal Engine a few very nice looking games decide to make, but a normal Unreal Engine 3 Game. Well, the setting (in a desert) is a bit new and sometime there is an above average usage of post processing filters.  Anyway, what you want the game to play for is the story. And this is the best presentation of a story I had in any shooter since ages. In fact I do not remember to be touched this much of a shooter ever. This experience is only something for very strong people. This is in fact the first 'Rated M' game I would say, it has this with a reason. This game has a strong and moving story. It is very enjoyable but in a very different way. I do not want to spoil anything, so I will not tell anything more, but if you can decide to play this game and think you do not want the normal quick action experience, play this game. It is the 'Schindlers Liste' or the 'Green Mile' of video games.  TL;DR Everybody who plays games and is an adult should play this game. It is a experience which will make your collection of gaming experiences richer than the most games you might consider to buy. So plz, buy this game and 'enjoy' the story.

This is a game which carries a very strong message. While other shooters glorify war through depiction of war heroes and other heroic acts, this is a reminder to all of us about the horrors of war. There are no war heroes in this game, nor heroic acts. All the scenes in this game were probably meant to show the disgusting truth of war, such as (might carry spoilers) abuse of civilian hostages, liberal use of inhumane weapons (White Phosporus mortar), progressive mental deterioration (in the first missions one of the characters took the matter lightly by slipping humor, as the story progresses he starts to feel weary and scarred), and general feelings of distrust, hate, guilt, and anger.  While the story and narrative of the game carries a strong message to the audience, the game fell short on its controls. Controls in this game might feel odd (spacebar for sprinting, what?) which may confuse gamers who are accustomed to WASD for movement and SHIFT for sprint. Multiplayer might also not the game's shining star.  In the end, Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter game that excels on dark narrative and storytelling, despite falling short to odd controls and multiplayer. I strongly recommend the singleplayer for its gritty and engaging story.  8/10

On the other hand, if you're looking for a good singleplayer story, then everything bad i just said about this game gets thrown out the window. I definitely recommend this game. However, there are some things you ought to know about it.   First, about the gameplay. It's your typical third person shooter, but it is well done. It is challenging, but generally not unfair. If you enjoy third person shooters, this should satisfy that desire.   However, I don't recommend this game because of the gameplay. The real reason to play this game is the story - an unfortunately rare case for military shooters. I don't want to spoil it, if you've somehow come across this game without knowing about the story, but it has much more depth and consideration than you might expect, that is much more befitting of the violence it contains.  Overall, this is a really incredible game - but it won't really make you feel good. If you want a mindless shooter - which can be a good release - there are better choices. But if you want a substantive story to accompany strong gameplay, Spec Ops is a great choice.

The difficulty curve feels natural and fair to me throughout.   Don't miss this game, it looks great, plays great, and has engaging gameplay with a rich and unique storyline that actually has you going 'What the ♥♥♥♥ just happened?' at times.

This game starts out very close to any other military shooter you've played but even at the start you know something is off and a little unsettling. Maybe it's the chaos of the post apocolyptic Dubai that the game takes place in or the American soldiers that you are constantly mowing down because they shot at you first right? If the main character, the hero, of the game thinks it's what is necesarry and good then it must be! Then you hit the half-way point of the game. If you didn't realize something was going on by now then prepare to be thrown out of your comfort zone into one of the most disturbing acts that you will ever have to commit in a video game. After this point you'll start to wonder why you are here? The original mission was recon not rescue or revenge. You were to radio in for evac if you discovered any sign of survivors but if your mission is completed why were you still fighting your way to the heart of the city? This game will make you feel like a horrible person. It will make you question why you even enjoy shooters it will throw atrocities of war into your face and point blank ask you if you are having fun yet. If you are enjoying what you have done. It will ask if you don't enjoy this then why are you still playing and it will carry this. It will call you a horrible person who loves to see suffering and throw it on until the very end. Now enough with the story and lets talk about the gameplay which is not nearly as great as the story. It is very standard third person shooter controls you can spring and take cover the aiming works well gunplay feels tight and the action is all there nothing much to write home about. There is some 'strategy' and by that I mean there is a single button dedicated to giving your two A.I. companions orders. Short of taking people out silently when you don't have a silenced gun you won't really be using this button. I'm not exactly sure how to wrap this review up but I seem to have forgotten any form of comedy while writing it. Oh well. Rating: did you actually read this whole thing? Spec Ops: The Line is not a fun game by any stretch of the imagination but as you play you come to realise that that really is the point of the game. It is not designed to make you feel good about what you are doing. Yager clearly had in mind that they would create a game which emphasised the message of the game over the mechanics of it. This message is then conveyed through a number of different techniques the most powerful of which is perceived choice. In the end you wont feel pleased with what Walker and his team have done but that is not to say that you will be overwhelmed with emotion either. Instead this game will sober you up from all of the other shooters on the market which hide the body count that you rack up behind a large stack of interesting in game mechanics and a compelling Hollywood esque story. But in the game this truly is what you make of it and according to one of the games writers Walt Williams one of the games endings is simply for the player to put down there controller and stop playing.

Controls and a couple of design flaws aside, Spec Ops: The line is one of the best games to come out of 2012. Anyone interested in an excellently executed examination and deconstruction of the shooter genre should give the game a play through.

An interesting, thought-provoking FPS experience that plays with tropes of the genre, providing meta-commentary on the disconnect between players and actual combat soldiers, exploring the consequences (and the illusion) of choice, and critiquing the notion of the 'good guy with a gun' in conemporary culture. For a long time people have accepted that not all movies and books should be fun, some of them are devastating and painful to experience, and Spec Ops the line is the first game that rejects “fun” and replaces it with something else. The characters are flawed people, the story is moving and it does all the without being edgy. Spec Ops is a mature game! Unlike so many other games that try and shock players into feeling something rather than eliciting a genuine emotional response, *cough cough* Call of Duty. I don’t want to spoil too much about this game but I’d definitely recommend playing it. I hope that more games like this are released in the future because while it’s not “fun” Spec Ops is very enjoyable.

Spec Ops: The Line is a remarkable FPS game with elements of Psychological Horror, putting the player in the middle of war torned Dubai after a devastating and unrelenting sandstorm hit the city and effectively cut it off from the rest of the world. It is from there on up to the player and his crew of Delta Force to figure out what's going on in the city, locate the missing Colonel and his soldiers, and try to save whatever survivors they can find.  Although the gunplay is so so, the control and cover a little clumsy, and the same with the squad commands; Spec Ops strengths lies in its storytelling aspect, its great acting and the deep, emotional rollercoaster that it pulls the player through.  For anyone who calls themselves gamer enthusiasts, this is a must have gaming experience, guaranteed to leave you both shaken and amazed at the end, like the bittersweet aftertaste of freedom after a bad relationship.

Gameplay is nothing new, but solid and entertaining enough.  The excellence lies in the games narrative, which is just ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic. To put it simply, it teaches you that there usually aren't any heroes in war, no matter what games like Call of Duty says. Of course, Spec Ops: The Line has its own gung-ho macho soldier moments as far as the gameplay is concerned, and i particularly noticed the ridiculous feature of having headshots make the targets head actually blow up, but I guess it's hard to criticize a specific genre and avoid all of said genres conventions, while still maintaining your position within that genre, and of course still being fun to play.  Anyway, just play it, you'll get what I mean. And if you buy it at 75% off, it's a steal.

I am not a big review kind-of-guy, but this is the best 'Go to cover, shoot, and move ahead' game I've ever played.  MY EXPERIENCE: The beginning starts off as a pretty normal duck-and-shoot kind of game, but it turns out to be a little bit more than that. The action really starts packing in towards the middle of the Campaign which makes the end one to die for.You are faced with dramatic and story changing choices at the end of Campaign. My heart was racing with adrenaline the whole last half hour of the game. Spec Ops: The Line really changed my opinion and outlook on war, which games like COD fail to do. OVERVIEW: Spec Ops: The Line really changes your insight on what really happens in war; the bad and even more bad. This game depicts an accurate, but gruesome picture of a US Battallion gone rogue in Dubai, who end up killing thousands of innocent civilians just for their own survival. You are a 3-man Delta team that is supposed to go in and save all the civilians, but quickly find out, you are the only ones here focused on saving the civilians. You then fight the US 33rd Battallion and forget that you ever knew them as they whiz bullets by your face. I'm not a big review guy, so I won't spoil all the good stuff for you.  This game is definitely worth a try. I loved it! Spec Ops: The Line is certainly worth atleast $5!

Spec Ops is a surprisingly intelligent game camouflaging itself as a typical third person military shooter. There are so many layers to the plot - the surface plot with twists and turns and surprises, the subplot with its own messages, then at the deepest layer is the subtext which in my opinion is what the game is *really* about.   It's difficult to convey what the game does subtextually, but suffice to say that normally a violent game like this would be steeped with what some pretentious game reviewers call ludonarrative dissonance - a strong disconnect between the plot and the gameplay. On the contrary, the narrative and gameplay in this game are tied together - they comment on each other. The purpose of this game and the messages it attempts to convey are the sum of the narrative and the gameplay.

TL;DR version: The game is fantastic, and slightly depressing. Great story, good enough gameplay. And now for the particulars.  Spec Ops: The Line is a big question mark for the military shooter genre, disguised as a 3rd Person Shooter. The major point of the game is the story, the journey of three Delta Force operatives within the doomed city of Dubai. The focus is on the progression and the change of the characters and the world that turns more and more surreal and a mirror of the madness you descend into.  You start the game as you would a lot others, shooting mostly arab-looking opponents, running and gunning into the outskirts of Dubai... but you will certainly not finish the game as you would most others. The twists and turns of who is the actual opponent is a very nice thing, morality gets murky very quickly and some of the intel you find will make you think a lot about your enemy (very nice format to introduce collectibles into a serious game). The only fixed point in the swirling madness you walk into is the main character's certainty that he is doing the right thing. You be the judge if that is the case....  Some of the most striking bits about this game are the visuals and the sound. It isn't the most technically impressive title, even considering its age, but the way the sand-filled city of Dubai is presented to you is simply stunning. A very important thing is that the visuals will evolve together with the story and the characters: in the beginning the world is what you would think it is, bleak desert, with some remnants of civilization hanging around, but as you advance into the Heart of Darkness, the landscape will change accordingly. Inside the crumbling towers you will find the luxury mixing with brutality, surreal scenes painted with lots of colors, contrasting very sharply against the state of mind of the characters.  The visual transformation of your character and your squadmates is equally impressive and important in driving home the messages of the story. You start out as proper looking soldiers coming to the rescue, but by the end of the game you will look like demons murdering dozens upon dozens of soldiers... and then the game will ask you: 'How many Americans have you killed today.' And you might feel an urge to put down the controller/mouse and walk away from the game at that point... it is one of the possible endings, refusing to finish the game.  The sound and voice acting evolves similarly. In the beginning of the team your small team of Delta operatives behaves and talks like you would expect from elite soldiers. Your opponents and the world around you also sound proper. But there is a very subtle change happening to all these things along the game. Your orders go from the likes of the calm 'focus fire on my target' command to bellowing furiously toward you comrade: 'I want him dead', and your squadmates will respond in the same way, from professional acknowledgment to a disturbingly savage war-cry.   The genius in all this evolution is that it happens almost unseen, and the atmosphere of the game is so powerful that you won't always notice the changes as they happen. You will just be surprised at some point of the game that... wait.... when did we start shouting obscenities at out enemies and each other? Why the hell did I just execute a wounded US soldier with utmost brutality? Why did I just gun down that civilian?  The 'tooltip' messages that pop up on loading screens will also change... at first they will be actual tooltips, but as the madness progresses those messages will turn increasingly more intimidating ('Do you feel like a hero yet?' 'If you were a better person, you wouldn't be here.'), rubbing the salt even deeper. That fact that the changes are subtle but powerful is the whole point of the game, as is the fact that it is very good at sucking you into its world and making you miss all these little details when it would still matter.  Gameplay-wise, Spec Ops: The Line is good enough to carry the story. The TPS shooting mechanics are a bit stiff, aiming isn't as smooth as it could be... but combat is gritty and action-packed enough to be entertaining on most difficulty levels. For the best experience I would recommend Combat Op or Suicide Mission difficulty depending on your skill. These can make the combat challenging enough that the whole 'war is brutal' message isn't lost, but not as unforgiving that the combat would blur out the message of the experience. The tactical part of the game is very shallow, you can command you squadmates to attack a target you choose, heal each other, and occasionally to do a specific action (stun, flush). It is very barebones, and the AI isn't particularly bright either, but it is good enough. 'Good enough' is the staple of Spec Ops: The Line's actual gameplay mechanics. It isn't really good, not very memorable in itself, but not bad either.  I do have one major problem with this game however: what the bloody hell are 'Kill x amount of people with y gun' kind of achievements doing in this game? Who's genius idea was that load of steaming something? Actually why are there even achievements for this game? That seems to be completely against the spirit of the game...

Spec Ops: The Line is a very important game, both in terms of narrative and medium. While its third-person-shooter mechanics are nothing new, it could be argued (and it has been) that this is intentional, and that the game isn't necessarily made to be a fun shooter. What it most certainly is, however, is a critical look at contemporary video game conventions and an attempt at addressing the issues that other popular shooters, such as the Call of Duty franchise or the Medal of Honor games, fail to do. It makes the point that these sorts of military shooters should be horrifying. It is one of the most self-aware games out on the market. Its narrative is one of depth and introspection. Play this game; not because it's fun, but because it isn't.

Spec Ops: The Line is a modern military shooter you play for the story.  The gameplay is, well, 'modern military shooter.' I think there is more gameplay variety in Candy Crush levels then in different modern military shooters. And Spec Ops: The Line proudly continues that tradition. OK, it does have this excitting new future where you can shoot out glass windows holding sand at bay so it drops on top of your opponents. Innovation!   Yet, its hard not to get the gameplay right with a hundred examples to pick from. Enough of the combat is tense and challenging that the game recieves passing grades for fire fights, but nothing really elevates it.  However, the story is absolutely phenomenal, albeit unoriginal as it is inspired by the Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness. Still, if you are going to copy, might as well copy from one of the best. In a fictional near future, a massive sand storm hits the city of Dubai destroying much of its infrastructure. However, a batalion of US soldiers, the 'damned' 33rd, attempted to evacuate and save civilians before and during the storm. However, all contact is lost with the city and the batalion. They are officially left for dead in a no man's land.  Until the game's protagonist (your character) Mark Walker, a member of Delta Force, is sent to make contact with any survivors. What begins as a recon mission quickly escaltes as the city is divided into factions at war with each other. Along the way, Walker tries to aggressively to play hero, and, well, mistakes are made. This is not a heroic fantasy where a world in peril can be saved from a villain by a good hero. So, you don't know how it will end, or what the price will be for simply to continue playing. Which paradoxically is a much stronger incentive to play than simply klling Nazis.

This game is a Trojan horse, a game made and hyped to look like your typical second-rate Call of Duty knock-off. It asks you to understand that mindset and be ready to be the absurd, invincible action hero. It creates the smoke and mirrors of a world of brutal warfare where manly men pose atop the carcasses of their enemies and give nary a thought to the dozens of friends they have lost in just the last five minutes.   Then, when you have lost yourself in that fantasy of false machismo, Spec Ops: the Line brutally pulls the wool off your eyes.  This game is more of a horror game than a military shooter. This game by design brings all of your posturing over your virtual heroism up to the fore just to take it away. The narrative is downright brilliant with a crisp and clean delivery, without delays or lengthy exposition. Spec Ops respects your intelligence - it expects you to see the horror of what happens and understand what it means beyond the game.  The level of attention to detail is striking. A full discussion of just how much thought the dev team put into making the player experience what has happened would take far too long, but I have to bring up one of my favorite touches. First, the comments made by the protagonist change as does his mindset. In the beginning of the game, he is composed and professional, sounding like a typical military shooter character. 'Tango down.' 'Agh, I'm hit.' 'Target the grenedier on top of the billboard.' As the events unravel, the voice stabs change - 'TANGO ♥♥♥♥ING DOWN!' 'HE'S DONE!' 'I WANT HIM ♥♥♥♥ING DEAD!' The enemy voice stabs do the reverse, at first disorderly and pained, but later robotic, flat, and full of jargon. Dehumanized. It's a chilling effect for those who open their ears.  The gameplay is a fairly standard third person shooter with decent artificial intelligence on the part of both the NPCs and the enemy. Movement is slowed to a realistic speed, enemies do occasionally seem to come out of semi-obvious spawn points, and your command over the NPC squad is limited to calling targets. As the game takes place in Dubai after an apocalyptic sandstorm, sand is sometimes used creatively for environmental kills and often used for harrowing firefights in the middle of a storm. There are the obligatory turret sections expected from this kind of game and they are the same turret sections you have blazed through since the early 2000's. Don't expect any of the big set-pieces you've seen before. Mechanically, they aren't there, and narratively, they do not make sense. Graphically, the setting is beautiful, mixing the evocative luxury of wasted Dubai with the stunning, more human, more personal suffering of a city on the brink. This is not the cartoony wasteland of Fallout, or the over-dark of a STALKER, but rather a level of anguish torn straight from images of real refugee camps.  But do not play Spec Ops for its average gun combat. Play it because it's a game that confronts the player like no other. This is not a heroic war fantasy to make you feel powerful. This is gaming's Heart of Darkness or Apocalypse now, trying to make you think about your wish to be a virtual hero.

Spec Ops:   The Line   The Feels is a gritty 3rd person shooter set out to put players through emotional torment as they question their actions while gunning down supposed allies. The purpose of the game is to smack those who have the mindset of 'war is awesome, I want to sign up in the military because games like Battlefield and Call of Duty make it look so cool' and show them the horrors of what being a soldier could be like, the consequences, the dark corners of a war. Soldiers can make really stupid decisions that can cost innocent lives and the repercussions could damage them mentally, something that Spec Ops is able to capture spectacularly well. That's the beauty of this game, you are not here to play just another military shooter, you're here for an experience that can only be understood once you played it. There are no heroes, no villains, just men with guns.     WAR IS HELL

Spec Ops: The Line can be summed up in one word: FUN. There is nothing innovative about this game. Everything is straightforward and quite linear. The choices you make along the way have almost no impact on how the story unfolds. These choices, however, will prompt you to act on your instincts.  SO:TL is a third person cover shooter yet the covering system is unreliable at times, and it will guarantee to annoy on Suicide Mission and Fubar difficulty. Vaulting over cover has to be precise or a melee command will be executed instead. Imagine being fired at and you suddenly pop out of cover to elbow the air followed by a 'You Died' message.   Technical issues aside, Spec Ops: The Line is a satisfying cover shooter. Events and story pacing is superb. The guns are varied. Switching firing modes or a grenade attachment adds a bit of tactical depth to the gunplay.   If you are looking to play mutilplayer online matches, look elsewhere. Invite only co-op can possibly add another 2 to 3 hours of gameplay on top of the 6 to 8 hours required to complete the campaign. Spec Ops: The Line is an underrated gem that deserves more attention. Buy it on sale and enjoy the ride.

Fantastic story.

Ammo is limited due to the circumstances you find yourself in and the game encourages you to pick up the weapons of fallen enemies. This is not your average military shooter power fantasy. In fact, it's the opposite: an experience that walks you through the gallery of military shooter tropes, methodically breaking each one apart.  With your face. You start the game as a murrikan macho dude ready to save the day. You end it as a broken wreck of a man who hasn't saved a single soul, but has doomed countless ones. Spec Ops makes you cross The Line to drive home a single point: as fun as military shooters might be, their morals are terrible, their implications are even worse, and their characters, the ones you are supposed to root for, are war criminals. The game is carefully constructed to make you feel guilty for having fun. Is it manipulative? Yes, sure. It is hypocritical? Probably. It is worth going through? Absolutely.

When it comes to gameplay Spec ops: The line does an ok job as a third person shooter, but where this game really does shine is in its story and the way it doesn't aim to glorify war but to reveal its horrors and the psychological effect it can have on soldiers. When you first start the game it may not seem like this but as you go on the plot of the game will start to take a darker tone and the objective of your squad's mission, which was to find and evacuate survivors, will change into a hunt for the man which Walker believes is responsible for the chaos in the ruined Dubai. As you go on your squad will begin to question the ambiguous nature of Walker's mission and so will you as the player, even going as far as to ask if the people you are killing are really your enemies. There will also be points in the game where you are forced to take actions for the narrative of the game that will make you question the morality of those actions, even the text on the loading screens will make you rethink your actions throughout the game. Once you reach the end of the game you will be left thinking and asking yourself one of the same questions that the game asked you 'Do you feel like a hero yet?', and no matter which of the four endings you get the answer will still be the same.

This game will make you believe you're the Hero, until you turn into something else entirely. You'll keep playing nevertheless, while the game crushes your soul with the horrible effects of your - generic wargame-ish actions.

While Spec Ops is a difficult game to recommend based on its mediocre gameplay, performance issues, and frustrating controls the story packs a real punch and is the sole highlight of the game. The 'Do you recommend this game, Yes : No' is very limiting here because it depends. If you are looking for a good game this isn't it. If you are looking for one with a great story that is a military game no less than you found it. In this 'I'm offended' generation where someone always has to be offended by something and demand its removal the devs went all out and didn't care who they offended. They had a message to send and pulled no punches.  Game wise Spec Ops The Line suffers. I was constantly fighting with the controls and couldn't help but be bored to death whenever the shooting started thanks to the mediocre mechanics and bad AI. It came to the point where I was trying to rush through the game just so I could be done with it and that's a shame because it somewhat took away from the impact of the story.   The visuals are average and the aliasing hurt my eyes but it runs worse than Crysis 3. On a rig equipped with a 3770K, 16 Gigs of RAM, and a GTX 780ti I was getting frequent stutters, shaky mouse movements, and framerate drops.   With that said the creators of Spec Ops The Line clearly had a vision and they must have fought tooth and nail to make it happen. What starts off as a cliché military shooter ends up as something far more. The story is grim, depressing, bold, and a big middle finger to military games which rely on unquestioning patriotism and make war seem like it's fun and cool. It is not afraid to tackle the horrors of war and PTSD. It's designed to make you feel uncomfortable and it's about time a military game goes this route.  It's a shame then that there isn't a good game here to compliment the work put in by the writers. I am glad to have experienced Spec Ops The Line but it is not something I can easily recommend.

I do NOT recommend this game. It's painfully clear that the makers were trying to make a point with the game, story and gameplay. But it's extremely heavy handed, in your face and sometimes makes absolutely no sense.  So let's start from the beginning. The game is a Modern Military Shooter and it's got every single trope from these games, including regenerating health, bland cover mechanics, billions of soldiers, rambo-style firing from the hip, unskippable cutscenes and more testosterone than a juvenile detention camp.  It tries to be dark, realistic and gritty, but then throws you in a situation where you mow down 50-60 enemies all on your own (or with your two teammates). There are even situations where AG (Air-to-ground) missiles strike the ground not five feet from you and all that results in is a bit of an action scene in slow-mo, a building falling apart but you escaping unscathed. It's got a serious problem with keeping it's setting and tone. Is it dark and realistic? Trying to make a moral point? Is it a dumb covershooter? It can't seem to make up its mind about what it's trying to be.  The gameplay is bland, bordering on downright dull. It's just moving to a battle arena area, mow down 30-50 enemies, move to the next cutscene, new arena. Rince and repeat. It's incredibly dull and if it wasn't for the story, I would've quit after less than half an hour. It's that dull.  It's very obvious the point of this game was to make a moral point in killing and what you're actually doing in a game like this. Killing hundreds upon hundreds of soldiers. Yet the game never gives you an option to stop and ponder these things. Nor does it give you any meaningful choices. Oh, so you want to berate me for using white phosphorous on a bunch of american soldiers, and accidently on a bunch of civilians? Sure, but then give me an alternate route! You can't berate me for making a choice where I had no other choice.   Then there's situations which are obvious 'shooter traps'. At one point, someone you care about is killed by an angry mob of civilians, and you're put in a situation where unless you wait for a few seconds, it's going to be the airport scene all over again. Try to walk through the civilians, they nearly one-hit kill you with a push. It's blindingly obvious that the game wants you to shoot the civilians so that it can complain about what a horrible human being you are later. Now, there's actually a way out of that situation that does not involve massacre, so I'll give the game that.  The game at one point makes a quip at how killing civilians isn't allowed in war and adds a contemptful 'But you don't even care'. Don't presume to know me, my dear game. It pisses me off.  But on the whole this game is frustrating, extremely heavy handed, DRENCHED in MMS tropes and has bland and dull gameplay. Unless you love these kinds of games, please stay away! It's raising some questions, but it does is so extremely 'in your face' that it just becomes tiresome and preachy.

This what it? This was the cult classic shooter every video game hipster this side of the solar system ranted and raved about? Really? Okay, where to begin...    First and foremost, the game was four hours on the normal difficulty. Four. That's about a dollar an hour for what I paid this game for on Steam, so whatever, But definitely not worth the $30 it's worth normally. Beyond that, the game doesn't really successfullly subvert the shooter genre like a lot of people like to say it does. Why? Because you, as the player, never have any real decisions to make. The game tries to make you feel bad for doing things, except you have no choice but to do them. If I could choose not to do bad things but I did them anyway, mistakeningly or otherwise, I might feel bad about the bad things my character does in the game. But I can't, so I don't. Beyond that, the story was pretty convoluted. Some of the crap the characters do is overtly sabotaging their mission and they don't seem to notice until after the fact.    The rest of the narrative is pretty much 'find this guy, so you can find that guy, so you can find THAT guy', and that's pretty much it. It's a quest to find a bunch of different dudes who are in the game for fewer than thirty minutes so you can find the next guy who will be in the game for fewer than thirty minutes and that's pretty much it. On top of that, the suppossed delta operators act like anything but. None of them seem like they've ever held a weapon before in their respective lives. The player character inexplicably has two rear iron sights on his rifle and fires it with the stock under his armpit. The dialogue is also horrible. Additionally, there are military inaccuracies out the wazoo. There are two officers in your 'squad', but delta doesn't recruit officers. A fireteam is at least four guys, but your team has three. The 33rd Battalion has way too many guys to actually be a battalion, and the guy leading them is also a delta officer (again, even though there's no such thing). Why is a spec ops guy leading an infantry unit? Who knows. This game makes zero sense. Moreoever, you carry about half the actual combat load of an actual soldier, so have fun constantly scrounging for ammo after you burn through your whopping 120 rounds in your primary weapon.     Your teammates are also completely useless. They can't do anything unless you tell them to, otherwise they just get in your way. Ocasionally, they'll even get downed and you'll have to revive them, even though there is no such system in place for your character. If you go down, you die. Which is horribly frustrating, considering you'll sprint when you mean to slide into cover and vice versa due to the bad controls. All in all, this game is just bad. It doesn't really succeed in anything it tries to do. The only part of the game that really got to me was one of the endings that you can affect, and even then, the game couldn't fight its compulsion to be lame and cut the awesome pan-out and the music just as the full effect of the scene was setting in.     The game's cutscenes are abrupt with rapid transitions and violent cut-outs of music. There are fewer than ten commonly-encountered weapons in the whole game, and none of them can be customized. Which, is kinda ridiculous, considering delta guys get absolute autonomy over their gear. Your companions are noisey and incompetent tag-alongs who constantly shout at you, giving away your position. Even the gunplay is mediorce at best. Buy the game and give it a go if it's on sale. Otherwise, avoid it like it's the plague. This game was atrociously bad.

Good story. Awful, agonizing gameplay. On each level, the game throws huge droves of enemies at you, presumably to make this heinously short game just a bit longer. However, the game itself is such a barebones, repetitive chore that it will take all the motivation you possess to pull yourself through it. Spec Ops has nothing more than the most basic mechanics present in every single shooting game, and yet it still manages to muck those up tremendously. Movement is horrendously clunky, sprinting is unresponsive, the cover system is buggy, and the control scheme is without a doubt the worst I've ever encountered. Sometimes I would stand up and get myself killed by accident because melee and vault over cover are mapped to the same button for whatever brilliant reason. Also, going into cover, as well as leaving it, requires you to sprint, which often times sent me bolting forward when I really just wanted to stand up. Would it be so hard to create a designated cover button like nearly every other cover based third person shooter? Normally, I would complain that this is a full price game that is only 4 to 5 hours long, but for every second I spent playing this game I just wanted it to end so that I could see this revolutionary plot twist everybody was talking about. At least this game does have an above average story, but every second of it is horribly marred by its painfully poor gameplay.

Okay, here's the summary; this game is BORING. The shooting mechanics are very basic, with absolutely nothing new or interesting. You do have a squad, but there are a grand total of 3 commands you can give, 2 of them situational, so all you really do is mark targets for them to shoot. The weapons are very generic, but frustrating, because ammo is limited and there is just enough weapon variety to run low or out of ammo regularly, because enemies simply won't use gun X for a while. Grenades are common but very under-whelming, best saved to dump on heavies and turrets. Enemy AI isn't bad, but again, nothing special, with the main difficulty coming from enemies spawning at different places and running onto the map with little to no warning, so you can't intelligently use cover until you learn their spawn patterns. Really, the game is mostly just holding back enemies in clear, distinct waves a couple of times at every checkpoint. Over and over. I guess this isn't that unusual or bad compared to similar games, but it's also why everyone gets those other games for MP, because the SP gameplay is so boring! There's no unique enemies or visceral combat or anything this game can call it's own, and ends up being completely unmemorable.  And I honestly don't understand the praise this story gets. Your characters are three dudes you know nothing about, at all. They don't act intelligently, they are not consistent, and the 'big choices' you make don't much matter. And those choices...okay, this is the laziest kind of 'choice' writing; completely unexpected, impossible-to-know things happen, meaning, your CHOICES don't matter, it's just dumb luck. It's like choosing to shoot a guy in the leg to NOT kill him, but you happen to shoot his lighter and he erupts in flame. Umm...okay. You tried to do the right thing, moving on. But no, the game tries to make this kind of random chance into a morality play. The overall plot is riddled with holes and is made VERY DRAMATIC only because PEOPLE keep YELLING and CURSING constantly! Stripped of that, it's actually not intelligent or clever; it may 'make you think', but as soon as you do, you'll see how idiotic everything is. Basic questions are not even asked in game; we are just supposed to not think about the blatant contradictions and not wonder why our heroes are doing what they are doing.  Yeah, this is not fundamentally different from every other brown/grey modern shooter. All they did was take the very basic stock story, and add hamfisted guilt, a few trippy scenes, and the theme of 'your choices matter!' while not allowing your choices to matter and delivered with the subtlety of a 2X4 to the neck. I LIKE good stories, but honestly, I would have preferred a simple but well-written story versus this failed attempt to do better, because instead of being 'out of the way' and forgetable, it's instead a headache that makes me go 'What? Why?!' every 10 minutes. Spec Ops: The Line is an excellent example of why I no longer trust video game reviewers. Somewhere along The Line between entertainment and art, curators and plebs alike decided that a game with a point was somehow exempt from basic rules of gaming. It’s like if Mona Lisa spat on everyone who looked at it we’d still consider it genre-breaking. Except, Spec Ops isn’t Mona Lisa, it’s a trite piece of undercooked antiwar masturbation that appears to fear rupturing an aneurism if it avoids a cliché. Admittedly, I am comparing it to my larger recollections of war stories, not the current state of the subject within games. Compare Spec Ops to Stanley Kubrick’s Paths of Glory and the chasm between entertainment and pacifism Spec Ops apparently thinks unavoidable appears more of an artificial border. That is to say, Paths of Glory is every bit as cynical as Spec Ops but with half the tedium. I am not the first to point out that Spec Ops is a horrible game. Its benefactors admit this with the caveat that it somehow lends credence to its message. The Cynical Brit said it “isn’t a good game per se, it’s deliberately mundane 3rd person shooter which makes you think about the horrors of war.” It’s the “deliberately mundane” that irritates me. A deliberately mundane game is often indistinguishable from an incompetently mundane one. Cover-based gunfights that can be best described as soggy could be a statement about the stupidity of war, or a testament to how hard it is to make crisp-feeling third-person firefights. Considering that Gears of War is the only successful such attempt in recent memory, it’s all too convenient to say the gameplay was supposed to be bland. The blurb from its Steam store page describes this allegedly meaningful mediocrity as “tactical squad-based Delta Force gameplay throughout a horizontally and vertically oriented world”. Perhaps I expect too much, but anyone who pens prose such as this should not be trusted to make any adaptation of the Heart of Darkness. The memorable part of the gameplay is being constantly overwhelmed by hugely boring enemies who appear to be completely fungible with the exception of a single heavy type, who by describing as ‘heavy’ I have already imparted more information about their humanity than the game ever bothers to. Which is another issue with the deliberately mundane hypothesis. The storyline meshes with the gameplay precisely not at all. As I stand knee-deep in American soliders I shot to death because they stood between me and the next cutscene I’m expected to find my accidental shelling of a few dozen civilians the moral low point and story high point of the entire affair. Why? Ten minutes ago I intentionally killed men whose principal crime was proximity, and now I’m expected to feel remorse over the ones I offed on accident? Perhaps the convenience of intentionality ran dry by this point in the plot, because apparently designing mundane gameplay does matter yet designing to murder does not. Who’s ever heard of manslaughter anyway? While I’m worrying about intentions, this game does an impressively bad job of concerning itself with mine. Sometimes, I was killed by the nameless faceless ‘baddies’ because I was too bored to be bothered to think about any kind of tactics. The rest of the time, I was killed because the game figures “run headlong into the enemy” and “cower beneath chest-high wall” are basically synonymous. Neither was any quick recovery possible, because unlike in Gears of War, the far superior gameplay progenitor of Spec Ops, I could not reverse my inertia with the tap of the ‘don’t-get-killed’ button. Instead, I stood to my full height, rearing my all-American chest to their all-American steel, slowly reoriented myself to our homeland and attempted to correct the game’s mistake. But allow me to judge this “Story Rich” and “Political” game by its story and politics. Besides the name Conrad, the only feature Spec Ops retains from the Heart of Darkness is inexplicable motivations. And I don’t particularly appreciate that in the original text. Why does the protagonist continue on? That his unwilling companions constantly question him only compounds the issue by making it apparent. The complete lack of confusion on his part lulls the player into a blind acceptance of the plot, as we are presumably supposed to feel about the soldier’s acceptance of their mission drift. If you’re wondering where the plot holes are, just list the plot points. Why does he continue on into the city despite his orders about the retaining wall? To save the soldiers he watched die? What about the rebels who kill those soldiers; why do they vanish? Why does he accept the CIA so readily, while accepting that his fellow soldiers must die? And at no point do his Delta force underlings question him. These are men who are better educated and generally older than the average soldier: Men who are trained to question things normal soldiers aren’t. Even at the end, the last underling can’t bring himself to actually defy the protagonist. He merely won’t go with him any longer. Apparently, Conrad’s existence is enough to throw the protagonist into a fit of vengeance but his murdering of fellow soldiers, disregard of common sense, morality, and orders isn’t enough to inspire anything but words from his compatriots. I suppose they made the mistake of not being player-controlled characters. The Heart of Darkness doesn’t work without xenophobia. Chinua Achebe was right to point out that the text portrays Africans as inhuman, but it’s a necessary literary move for the text to work as a whole. It may be wrong, but you can’t just take the xenophobia out and expect the story to survive. Unless you’re Spec Ops. There are no foils for “good” Europeans to be compared to within the game. No “savages” on the shore to provide a visceral reminder of what the main characters are pretending not to be. All that’s left is people acting strangely. The ideology of imperialism cannot even be mocked if there are no apparent victims to it. And the handful of quivering refugees are as easily regarded the victims of the sandstorms as they are of the American military industrial complex. My principal emotions from playing the entirety of this quagmire of a game were frustration, confusion, and apathy. Frustration with the gameplay which clearly hated itself, confusion as to why any of the characters were doing almost anything they did, and apathy at the results of the decisions I didn’t understand. If this game is political, what political views should I take away from it? That we should be careful before dropping mortars on thermal signatures? That Delta Force commanders should not have total jurisdiction over places at which they just arrived? There is no political message here that is any less tedious or obvious than the game itself. Unless you need an eight-hour reminder that killing is bad (m’kay), stick to Bioshock for literature-inspired gaming.

Essentially this game is Army Of Two: Desert Reskin Edition ft. meatheads and a good twist ending.   The only reason this game has good reviews is because the Spec Ops community suppresses negative ratings by downvoting them into oblivion. If you actually want to see unbiased reviews, look at the 'funny' section where a few have surfaced through. I know people will gripe about me only having 50 minutes played. I had to use a custom launcher because it kept crashing on startup. This review will cover the mechanics first, then the plot.  This game is so linear its basically a 5 hour movie that pauses itself every minute or so for you to unpause it with a quicktime event or pressing a button to climb over something. The guns feel awful, never run out of ammo, and you'll never use anything the enemy isn't carrying at the time. Everything consists of setpieces with less thought put into them than MoH Warfighter. You will shoot enemies in a linear environment from cover for about 3 rooms, have yet another encounter with a turret that lasts all of about 5 seconds, then predict perfectly that you will be ambushed by infinite waves of enemies. In these ambushes you have to simply rely on trial and error and waiting. In every ambush there is a special spot you're supposed to be or you will be killed. For example, in the first ambush you have to run across an open field of sand to a broken building and get behind one of two pieces of cover. Lets say you picked the left, you'll be blown up with a rocket launcher setpiece and killed instantly. You restart, try to fight back and get killed within seconds because you want to have a good time, I guess. Eventually, after a few retrys, you'll find the magic position that won't get you killed, sit there for about 3 minutes until another setpiece is activated and you somehow all get away unscathed. You will look around and suddenly realize that you are now conveniently at the exact location you were heading to in the first place.   This game introduces nothing innovative whatsoever other than the option of shooting a window about every 30 minutes to drop sand on enemies. It seems like more of a gimmick to me than anything else. The movement couldn't even be spared, either. Imagine if Gears of War and Army of Two had a crippled child that was put on the indie games section of XBOX 360. Spec Ops just a step above that. It also doesn't help that the friendly AI is constantly in your way and consistently fails to understand orders outside the context of linear setpieces, which is always a 'press M3 to continue this game' resulting in your teammates actually doing their jobs.  Since everyone regards this game so highly due to its story and 99% of the plot is driven by cutscenes, I'm going to look at as a movie. If this was submitted for a film class, I'd give it an A-. I enjoyed the dramatic shift in tone and the twist endings, but that's all that really stuck out. It feels a bit shoehorned at times but I pushed through the generic cliches of modern shooters that is spec ops to reach the ending and the finale was great. However, it didn't make up for the lack of intuitive gameplay. My only qualm for the plot is the poor character development for everyone other than the main character and his squad. There weren't any memorable enemies and the leaders of the various factions you fight are basically just 'guys.' They don't have anything special to them and I'm bound to forget them within a week or two from now.   Scores with 5/10 being average Gameplay: 2/10 Story: 8/10 Overall for the game itself: 3/10  If you really want to enjoy this game, please do yourself a favor and just watch the cutscenes online and save $30 and 4 hours of your time. The plot is really the only thing Spec Ops: The Line has going for it.

A game with a lot of potential it fails to live up to. (Fairly) mechanically sound, Spec Ops: The Line attempts to bring the realities of war, the sanctity of life and the difficulty of moral choices into a genre where it simply doesn't work. It's a pity; the game is visually and audibly stunning and features excellently-scripted cutscenes that try very hard to bring home the game's thesis; the problem is that between those scenes you as a player are mowing down hordes of faceless enemies, undercutting the ideas brought into discussion. The 'Kobiyashi Maru' false choice that you are (repeatedly) faced with is exceedingly disingenuous as you are forced to decide between an immoral act or... not playing the game anymore. Continuing, of course, you are criticized for your 'choice.' I understand what the creators were attempting and applaud the attempt. There are a great many things this game does well - voice acting, music, dramatic tension, various interesting gameplay elements that utilize the environment in ways that most shooters are too lazy to attempt - but the key failing to live up to potential will leave you disappointed after an exceedingly (6 hour) short campaign.

In most first-person shooters, the nameless hero guns down hundreds if not thousands of faceless enemies but that hero never shows any regret or impact from all of his murder and mayhem. The 'hook' of Spec Ops The Line is 'what if the hero owned up to his kill-spree'? But despite these shades of Apocalypse Now, this message is toothless; a tale about the morality of choosing to kill loses its bite when the game railroads you down a narrow path. If there is literally no other way to proceed, the impact of 'choosing' to become a ruthless killer is lost because there is *no choice*; had the game offered multiple ways of bypassing the enemies then perhaps the desired effect would have been achieved, but as it stands the story is pointlessly preachy. It doesn't help that the setting - an endless dust storm that buries a modern city - is so unbelievable, or that none of the characters are in the least bit relatable. Anyway, I am frankly tired of this endless string of antiheroes in modern FPS games; it's become as trite and overdone as all the other standard cliches used in every other modern-warfare shooter.  But even aside from the overbearing plot, the game play is hardly anything to write home about; it's an uninspired cover-based shooter. The map design is thoroughly unimpressive and the low-poly graphics looked extremely dated (especially the pathetic explosions, which seemed fifteen years out of date). The AI was braindead (as usual), with the usual 'run behind cover and poke head up every ten seconds' routines that seem to be the norm for the genre. This was made all the worse since each skirmish long overstayed it welcome, with far too many spawns. And for a game whose main theme was the horror of war, most battles were remarkably bloodless, with enemies falling dead with barely a mark on them (the sole exceptions were scripted events). In the end, despite its worthy attempt to raise the level of discourse, Spec Ops was an unlikable game in every aspect.

To be honest i was disappointed. When i saw Zero punctuation's review i was very hyped for what i would get, but in the end it didn't really got to me.  The game was praised for being a masterpiece of modern shooter due to it's 'self aware' story, where it isn't the call of duty's nor battlefield's usual routine of 'Grrrrrr X nation has turned againts 'MURICA, TERRORISTS, KILL KILL KILL'.  The game is set in Dubai, but it's future Dubai and it's buried unter 500 ******* meters of sand. You are playing as the commander of a special squad, forged out of you and two friends (one is black, cause there's always a black guy [no offense]).  The gameplay consists of running between cover to cover, shooting americans (I'll get to that) and dying quite alot. The thing is it gets really dull quite fast. Your drones squad mates shoot almost everything for you, can heal each other, can throw infinite stun grenades when the game feels like you don't know how to defend yourself, snipe distant enemies and all that with the click of a button. It's the usual problem where the game treats you like a child. Another aspect is sand, which is laid in strategic locations for you to shoot at and then it drops on enemies and enemies die. Whoo hoo. Some aspects are quite nice but at the same time make you over-powered, like when you can crouch when you controlling a stationary machine gun, to make you an offensive beast while still hard to get attacked (yeah you lose some accuricy big deal). The weapon variety isn't that great, one or two weapons for each kind (shotgun, pistol, assult rifle) and that's it. Ammo is quite scarce in the start of the game so you'll pretty much have to rely on the enemy's flavor of the day. HOWEVER, the AI is really really good, even at medium difficulty it will try to flank you, use grenades to smoke you out of cover and will activly seek for you. The cover system and the 'last seen system' is very simillar to Splinter Cell: Conviction, which i really liked, so that's good. I'm disappointed there is almost no sneak option whats so ever, even though there are silencers for quite alot of weapons, feels like a missed oppertunity.  The graphics are pretty good, to be honest. I liked the little detail where if you step on sands in leaves trails of steps. The scenery is beautiful, everything makes you feed like you're really in the deserted (hu hu pun intended) city of Dubai, and that's a big plus.  Story (Spoilers):   The game's story is based on you have to report back to HQ what happened to a whole US division, called 'The dammed 33rd' led by a crazy general called konrad. For the two first missions you kill arabs cause, they are arabs and this is a modern shooting game, and for the rest of the game you kill americans, because in the third quest you get shot by some of them. Now the game starts and try make you feel bad for it because you shoot your fellow americans but    I feel like they deserve it after all of those arab/russian killing games out there.    We are told by the game to shoot them, and there is no other option but shoot them, and the game doesn't do a good job of making me feel bad for it.    They try to kill us so we have to try and kill them cause self defense right? (Sounds familiar America?)  There was also the REALLY annoying mechanic of badly written choices and the inconsistent tone the characters were having. For example there's a part where you have to make a decision whether to save a CIA agent in order for him to help you in the mission, but in the process risk civillian lives. One of your mates tell you to save the guy, and the other tell you to let him die in order for the civillians to live. Then in like 3 scenes after, you have to (HAVE TO) drop white phospherous bombs onto a main camp of american troops. Although you don't have a choice in this one, the squad mate who wanted to save the agent now isn't willing to help you with the operation of the mortar because it will kill tons of people, and the one who wanted you to save the civillians now just goes 'meh what the hell lets burn them all' and I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off bad. Then the game makes a HUGE scene of you and your squad walking in the burning camp, trying to make you feel bad for what you've done, but i just couldn't sympathise because the game didn't let me NOT to use the mortar, and I'm being punished for something I had no real responsibility over. Also, the entire game the game tries to make you feel bad for killing americans, and the it puts you on a helicopter with a mini-gun, flies you around a building full of amecian troops who can't really do anything bad to you, and tells you to mindlessly gun the place down. Almost every choice has no real effect on the story besides what achievement you get, because the story writes itself down in such a way it will always be the same outcome. In the CIA agent example, even if you choose to save him (and by the way no civllian dies because for some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ reason they aren't shown) he dies from the wounds of the following firefight, so it doesn't matter one bit what you choose. The end is playing the psycological mind-♥♥♥♥ route, saying that the general was dead for weeks and you're just crazy who imagined it all, and shows like how everything was really like (you were talking to yourself, things that you saw were alive were actually dead ETC.) For me it was the dumbest part of the game, because     The game fails to explain many holes after this, making it very dull and shallow.    It opens the possibility that all the americans were actually arabs or something, because you're crazy and you imagined it all.    The player is expected to believe that his two squad mates silently followed him as he talked to the air and shot dead bodies.    The ending scene is decided by one click of the mouse. Then some 'deep and sad' things are narrated in you character's voice, depending on you mouse click, the content varies a bit, and it's game over. I find it interesting, that Spec Ops: The Line got 'Very Positive' user reviews. People talk about 'realistic damage' while complaining about 'too long regeneration times'. Even though the story seems good - the gameplay isn't.  - The game isn't refined for 3rd person. More than often your character stands in your own way of view resulting in you getting shot from an enemy that would be clearly visible in 1st person. - Usability is a mess. Sometimes there are cutscenes which you can't skip. The savepoint is right before that cutscene. So, if you die at higher difficulty levels (i.E. 'FUBAR') it'll get played over and over and over and over and over again. Yeah, I got it, they're rounding up civilians. Again, and again, and again. - The AI is very bad. Enemies only try to rush you in groups, or they fall one after another while running up stairs without even reacting. Your team is mainly occupied with blocking your sight or not following you - sometimes they rush forward though and if they weren't almost invincible they'd be dead in a second. Sometimes they even shoot through walls. - The game is, as it is with many mainstream-shooters today, very unrealistic. The most unrealistic things are theweapon damage and the health recovery. And how the soldiers behave. In fact you play rogue soldiers who fail following orders and then you get blamed for 'decisions' in a 'all war is bad and you are bad' manner.  I didn't play it for a while... and now I remember why I stopped playing Spec Ops: The Line. The idea was good, but the implementation is a mess. All in all it's a good game with nice textures as long as you don't know anything about weapons, military operations or other stuff. If you have at least a bit of a clue you'll hate the game, because Spec Ops: The Line is very good at one thing: Destroying the high opinions you've may got from all the good reviews. If you're new to the shooter genre or you play mainstream-shooters - go for it, you could happy with it. To the rest: Keep away.
